The book was written with one purpose in mind: to explain all the possible ways in which a multiverse could arise, given our current understanding of physics. As such, it is not as useful as his other two books. The author's first book explained the current state of string theory, with a multiverse being but a possibility of the theory. His second book delved into the philosophy of reality, given the physics as we know it, again, positing a multiverse as a possible result from string theory. In this book he seems at times almost wishful upon the existence of the multiverse.In other words, the author is not doing physics in this book. He is not even doing physics education. In this book he is an advocate for the multiverse. He wants this multiverse to exist for two reasons, as he hints in the book. For one, there is no need then to explain why the universe is as it is. After all, in a multiverse all sorts of possible universes exist, and this one just happens to be one of them. Thus, a multiverse presumably absolves him from explaining the world (which I should point out is his job as a physicist). Second, if the multiverse exists, then the same mechanism that creates the multiverse creates the universe we happen to live in: and thus there is a mechanism in sight for the beginning of our universe, a puzzle which has haunted atheist physicists since forever. And furthermore, maybe the multiverse is eternal (even if our universe itself got started in some way by the multiverse), thus eliminating the need for any Creator agent.It boils down to trying to explain existence without God, purely in a materialistic way, even when our current established theories posit a beginning to the Universe which they cannot account for. Thence comes the wistfulness (and almost grabbing-at-straws despair) to come up with a multiverse, ANY multiverse.Not surprisingly, all of the author's candidates for a multiverse end up being mere possibilities---some more plausible than others. He is scientist enough to admit this, I must say, though I would emphasize the word "possible" a lot more than he does. (1) The Quilted Universe makes use of an infinite universe to create an infinite array of quilt universes. This infinite quilt, by the the nature of infinity, implies that any part of the universe (any square on the quilt) will necessarily repeat infinitely often, or---even more commonly---will repeat except for some particular feature (thus bringing about duplicate or parallel worlds). Of course, it assumes a completed infinite expanse.(2) The Inflationary Multiverse posits eternal inflation, which, when completed, COULD yield an infinitude of pocket universes, each of which is infinite in extent. But he needs eternal inflation for this, and even then he might only get a single universe (and not an infinitude of pocket universes). Finally, the author seriously confuses here a completing infinity with a completed one.(3) The Brane Multiverse comes from string theory, and essentially says that each universe could be a Brane (a 3D version of strings). Firstly, string theory is highly speculative. But if it is right, it definitely allows for branes, though it does not require them. Even if branes did exist, it is not at all guaranteed that universes are the sort of things which branes can contain (perhaps branes are simply energy blobs, or random super-exited particles inside the universe), nor is there a particular reason why our entire universe would live in one of those branes, nor why other universes (if they existed) would also live in branes. Granting all these assumptions, it is possible that there are plenty of parallel universes, each inhabiting its own brane, eternally flying through this multidimensional braneworld.(4) The Cyclic Multiverse posits two braneworlds close together in a multidimensional Braneworld cyclically colliding with each other to produce cyclic Big Bangs (and resultant cyclic universes) in each brane. This seems to me to be piling assumptions upon assumptions. Even if the Brane Multiverse existed, who is to say that any two Brane universes would end up being close to each other? And who is to say that they would have just the right mass, and that they would cyclically collide with one another in just the right frequency, with just the right velocity, with just the right force, and at just the right angle to produce cyclic Big Bangs (a Multiverse in time) of which the current observable universe in but a cycle? Too many coincidences!(5) The Landscape Universe comes into being when string theory cannot specify any single set of parameters for the fundamental physical constants---despite the fact that this is what was hoped of it years ago. In fact, string theory---just like Quantum Field theory---simply allows for any number of choices for the physical constants, without singling any one set of them. As far as string theory is concerned, they could almost be anything. In fact, string theory MULTIPLIES almost ad naseum all the possible values for each of the fundamental constants thanks in part to the eleven dimensions necessary for the theory. The Landscape Universe simply posits that all of these values could conceivably (and physically) happen, and that perhaps they do happen in the parallel universes made possible by the Inflationary Multiverse (or pocket universes within our own universe). The math and the physics allow it, the author states, therefore it could very well happen.(6) The Quantum Multiverse is the repetition of the speculative theory that every possible possibility in a quantum function finds a physical realization in a parallel universe, each of which the other "I"s, in their own specific universe, experiences. The main motivation comes from the incompleteness of quantum mechanics: because we do not have a good theory of the quantum wave collapse upon measurement---and must rely on ad hoc and artificial methods to manually re-adjust the wavefunction after every measurement/collapse---perhaps we should instead follow the math, which does not model any collapse at all, and postulate the existence of all possible results in parallel universes, so that the physical system is in fact modeled by the same equation before and after measurement. I suppose that one must give the author points for having so much confidence on the math. As he points out, Einstein did not believe all the implications of the equations of General Relativity and thus missed out on predicting some very exciting discoveries. But, what I find most troublesome is that he believes that parallel universes are less preposterous than the alternative mathematics two other physicists have developed---which he himself cites---, and which mathematics specifies quantum mechanics, while at the same time providing a mathematical consistent modeling of wavefunction collapse. A specific form of quantum mechanics (and consistent with it) is more preposterous than parallel universes? Really? On is almost compelled to argue that Occam's razor (a form of which states that "entities must not be multiplied beyond necessity") should surely apply here.(7) The Holographic Multiverse is the closest this book comes to physics. In fact, the author is really expounding here the holographic principle, which seems physically plausible. The idea behind the principle is that physical processes happening in some contained volume have some counterpart physical processes happening on the boundary of said volume, and that it is possible to translate between these two sets of physical processes. Now, such idea is not at all outlandish. It holds up mathematically in the Divergence and Stoke's Theorems, for instance,---and in Electromagnetism, which uses these two theorems extensively. The author applies this principle to black holes in a mathematical toy brane multiverse (with low gravity), obtaining very sensible and plausibly physically demonstrable results. Not sufficiently unambiguously to conclude the existence of a stack of branes, but sufficiently consistently to obtain the known result that a black hole would be seen as a source of Hawking's radiation at its boundary with the rest of the universe (that is, at the event horizon). Where the author flies into fancy is when he speculates that the reality as shown by the boundary physics is actually more real and has primacy over the physical processes going on in the solid which the boundary encloses. That is, he speculates that the holographic principle implies reality is akin to a hologram---where the 2D light etches on film are the real physical processes and where 3D projections are simulated consequences of these physical etches---instead of being akin to a shadow on a wall---where the 3D processes are the reality and have primacy over their projections on the wall. He offers no justification for choosing holograms over shadows. Thus, the author comes up with at least one other parallel universe at some universal boundary which mimics (or controls, he would say) the physical processes going on in our physical universe.(8) The Simulated Multiverse is a computer program. A very good computer program. As good a computer program as can be programmed and implemented with future technology. So good a computer program that the line between reality and programmed reality ceases to exist. Or rather, a multitude of such computer programs---as many as can in principle (and in actuality) be created by any and all our descendants and the simulated people they simulate in their realistic computer programs. Here the author does admit that this will only work if sentience is a matter of functionality and is emphatically not a property of a super-physical entity (such as the soul) or a property which cannot be abstracted from physical brains into computer circuits. Also, he admits that maybe there is a physical limit as to how good those simulations can be... Perhaps only the computable universes can be simulated, of which he does not know if our inverse is part. Given the assumptions he makes, he cannot discount that he is living in a simulated universe. Ultimately, he running up against philosophy here. As a philosophical concept, I can admit the possibility of simulated universes; as a physical concept, I am much more skeptical.(9) And finally he throws reason out the window in the Ultimate Multiverse. Although, to be fair, he doesn't buy into this one. He includes it merely for completeness. In this philosophical universe (which was dreamed up by one of his philosophy professors), anything which is logically and/or mathematically possible becomes its own universe. Thus, there is no need to explain why anything is the way it is, since, if the anything is logically consistent, it is then realizable in some universe. "Why isn't the sky black? But it is, in some universe. We just happen to be living in one that isn't". And there is no more need for why, ever. All you need is to show consistency---mathematical and/or logical. Thankfully the author draws the line somewhere.(9) & (6) It strikes me that proponents of the Ultimate Multiverse and the Quantum Multiverse would benefit from deep study of a difference that preoccupied the best Medieval minds (back when people used to know how to do philosophy)---namely the difference between a "contingent" world and a "actual" world. This difference has not entirely gone out of style. It is not very long ago that the famous logician Göedel used it in his private (not published by him) papers to try to show logically the existence of God. If there is anything that the proponents of the Quantum and the Ultimate Multiverses are trying to get at it is surely the very real concept of a "contingent" world. And if the concept is "real", in what sense is it real? Mathematicians, certainly, will often experience those "contingent" (mathematical) worlds as very mathematically real. And I sympathize tremendously. I myself feel very strongly that there must be *something* existentially true about logically and/or mathematically consistent systems (I am somewhat of a Platonist, after all). But I very much doubt that the existential *something* is of necessity physical. But I do have an advantage over the author on this one: I am not a physicalist---that is, someone who believes that "it's all physics". And I am dualist enough to believe that the world is more than abstract math.

I found this book to be a very good explanation of the theories of multiple universe that are being bounded about by M-theorists and other modern quantum physicists. This book sets the clear tone that has to be answered by Christians and others who believe in absolutes. But reading this book, one has to remember that physics research/conclusions changes. Books written about black holes in the 1980s, for example, have to be scrapped in light of modern math being worked out.*SPOILER ALERT*The book closes with a long diatribe by Greene on how nothing in our world may actually be real, we could all be living in a simulated multiverse. After all, we see how video games like The Sims and research into artificial intelligence are evolving quickly; it's not hard to think about how our grandchildren may be manipulating simulated life, so maybe we're actually living in such a scenario and everything we do is more or less dictated by a game player. And what about the world the game player lives in? It could also be simulated, and he could be a simulation himself! You end up with an infinite loop of simulations...until what? Greene doesn't say. Greene doesn't even think to mention DesCartes "I think, therefore I am." If I'm doubting what Greene is saying then I must necessarily be thinking, and I reject the notion that my myriad of doubts are simply simulated by someone running my life like The Sims. It's clear why Stephen Hawking can say that modern philosophy hasn't kept up with physics (The Grand Design). Modern physics would move philosophy back a thousand years.But I give this book 5 stars for clearly elucidating the theories of the multiverse and explaining where the most modern physics are.Research into inflation-- the rapid expanse of the universe from proton-sized to the holder of galaxies in the blink of an eye-- has important implications for how we view our world and philosophy. Assumptions that the universe is finite and began at a specific instant in time are being challenged by M-theory. If the universe is infinite, then it has always existed and there are also multiple universes. If the universe is finite, then there are not. Greene writes that experiments with the Hadron collider are basically trying to find out whether we're living on a brane universe. If it can be determined we live on a brane, then it is much more likely that our universe is one of many. Greene states at the outset that he is not sure, and that much cannot be proven. But how you look at cosmology has deep implications for how you view your own humanity. 7 billion years ago, universe sped up its expansion and it's still rapidly expanding. So, what happened 7 billion years ago needs to be explained.The particals called "inflatons" necessary to explain the process of inflation are theoretical. That's a problem with physics that Greene addresses- is any of this theoretical speculation on things that cannot be actually proven still be classified as "science?" Science means testable hypotheses, can any of these be tested? A hypothesis simply sets conditions that can later be tested (at least in theory), which means that the various ideas thrown about by cosmologists are science, according to Greene.Greene goes through all the various possibilities for multiverses:Table 11.1 Summary of Various Versions of Parallel Universes1. Quilted Multiverse: Conditions in an infinite universe necessarily repeat across space, yielding parallel worlds.2. Inflationary Multiverse: Eternal cosmological inflation yields an enormous network of bubble universes, of which our universe would be one.3. Brane Multiverse: In string/M-theory's braneworld scenario, our universe exists on one three-dimensional brane, which floats in a higher-dimensional expanse potentially populated by other branes - other parallel universes.4. Cyclic Multiverse: Collisions between braneworlds can manifest as big bang-like beginnings, yielding universes that are parallel in time.5. Landscape Multiverse: By combing inflationary cosmology and string theory, the many different shapes for string theory's extra dimensions give rise to many different bubble universes.6. Quantum Multiverse: Quantum mechanics suggests that every possibility embodied in its probability waves is realized in one of a vast ensemble of parallel universes.7. Holographic Multiverse: The holographic principle asserts that our universe is exactly mirrored by phenomena taking place on a distant bounding surface, a physically equivalent parallel universe.8. Simulated Multiverse: Technological leaps suggest that simulated universes may one day be possible.9. Ultimate Multiverse: The principle of fecundity asserts that every possible universe is a real universe, thereby obviating the question of why one possibility - ours - is special. These universes instantiate all possible mathematical equations.The theoretical universe where absolutely nothing exists would exist the set of universes contained in #9 above. (Wrap your head around that.) There is much history on research attempting to determine whether or not the cosmological constant equals zero. The size of the cosmological constant matters greatly for the formation of galaxies and such. Putting it in the equation makes a difference, as does its magnitude. So, a physicists' assumption on the magnitude of the cosmological constant has huge implications for how you look at the universe and humanity. How many universes needed to exist for it to be reasonably possible that one containing our exact cosmological constant could exist? Greene works that out.Cyclical cosmology purports that the universe had no beginning or end, it exists in an infinite loop. This conflicts with the law of entropy, which is observed in our universe, that things are moving from order to disorder-- necessitating a beginning point. Greene explains how modern views combine the theory of relativity with cyclical cosmology to find a way around the need for a big bang. It's complicated, and he at least explains what the math looks like at some points.There is plenty on Calabi-Yau shapes, and Calabi-Yau spaces. I don't get it, honestly.Greene takes a long look at the math's implications for the anthropic principle - the philosophical consideration that observations of the physical universe must be compatible with the conscious and sapient life that observes it. Some proponents of the anthropic principle reason that it explains why the Universe has the age and the fundamental physical constants necessary to accommodate conscious life. As a result, they believe it is unremarkable that the universe's fundamental constants happen to fall within the narrow range thought to be compatible with life (wikipedia). In other words, the universe is as it is because we're here. But Greene explains the multiverse with the analogy of a shoe store-- there are plenty of pairs of shoes and one of them must match your feet. The Milky Way is one of an infinite number of galaxies, and happens to be just the one that can sustain us, which we shouldn't find remarkable.Also from wikipedia:The anthropic idea that fundamental parameters are selected from a multitude of different possibilities (each actual in some universe or other) contrasts with the traditional hope of physicists for a theory of everything having no free parameters: as Einstein said, "What really interests me is whether God had any choice in the creation of the world." In 2002, proponents of the leading candidate for a "theory of everything", string theory, proclaimed "the end of the anthropic principle"[33] since there would be no free parameters to select. Ironically, string theory now seems to offer no hope of predicting fundamental parameters, and now some who advocate it invoke the anthropic principle as well.In the end, Greene hypothesizes that we're all in a simulation. Perhaps even the laws of physics we experience in this world are programmed into the simulation and may not hold in other simulated universes. Perhaps they are also accidents or unsolved problems in the code of the program being run that we inhabit (seriously, this is the best physics can do). I read a recent interview with Greene that faith and a belief in a Creator are not incompatible with physics (though he rejects any literal interpretation of Genesis) but it's clear that an infinite universe-- with no beginning or end-- needs no creator or creation point. I do not think Greene explained well how to reconcile what we know about a Big Bang -- that there was a beginning of the universe-- with the inflationary infinite loop. Much less how we can pinpoint the increase in the speed of the expansion 7 million years ago when such measurements are pointless if the timeline is infinite in both directions.Greene makes an interesting point that the human eye only evolved to see certain types of radiation-- like light, which contains information (his only foray into biology). Other types of radiation and information remain hidden to the naked eye. I've never seen an atheist explain how the light came to hold that information, except for Greene's simulated universe explanation. How did the eye know that the information was there to be processed? This is a problem for biologists, much less physicist-philosophers like Greene and Hawking. If Greene's infinite universe with infinite multiverses is correct, then we are all just a random compilation of molecules (as stated by Greene). At this juncture, it would appear physics is incompatible with evolutionary biology. Biologists purport that everything evolved in response to the results of trial-and-error processes that necessitate cells understanding information and responding accordingly (Richard Dawkins & company don't explain where that information came from, either). In the Greene/Hawking philosophy, it was purely random. Yet, they both agree that life is dependent upon information. This seems, to me, to be quite a contradiction (rather than just a paradox).This book is important because Greene alludes to the implications modern physics has for philosophy, and therefore ethics, human rights, theology, etc. Every Christian should read it as well as every atheist and respond with their own coherent philosophical critiques. I hope to read physicist Lee Smolin's The Trouble with Physics for a critique of Greene's string theory/M-theory from some of his own colleagues.

One of my eyebrows was still raised after reading Richard Dawkins’ assertions that the structure, process and function of RNA/DNA may have appeared spontaneously (after which everything else just sort of fell into place), when I picked up a copy of Brian Greene’s The Hidden Reality. Damned if my other eyebrow didn’t go up. The very notion of infinite universes and particle arrangements is indeed stimulating and fun to think about. I have no qualification whatever to question Professor Greene’s word that the mathematics behind string theory gets us there. Given the pesky intrusions of quantitative analysis, I also rather like the idea of being freed from the burdens of more familiar probability assessments, despite worrying that it opens the door to a kind of “infinity of the gaps.” Who’d have thought that Professor Dawkins was aiming too low? No more need to worry about the appearance of membranes, metabolism, DNA and flight ready Boeing 747s for that matter, with or without strong winds and junkyards. Arguably, evolution itself becomes unnecessary as whole universes identical in particle arrangement to our own have and will pop into existence with infinite frequency. To be sure, infinite universes maintain identical particle synchronicity throughout their complete multi-billion year histories as a matter of pure chance. Golly. But of course there are infinite parallel yous and mes, from zygote to the present; every event, every movement, every thought, every platelet identically conjured, shaped and positioned. If Professor Greene spontaneously materializes on your Starbucks line, just move along to the register – a comparatively modest event. It’s all just the (insidious) nature of infinity. But there are important assertions more within the public domain where I think Professor Greene and other celebrity scientists get bolloxed up.How often must I read that the latest scientific theory spells another cosmic demotion for the earth and life on it, akin to Copernicus’ (and Darwin’s) dethroning of such? It’s a shame that the original luminaries have missed out on so many fascinating techniques and discoveries since, but I’m not so sure they’d go along with prevailing discourse in their names or on their behalf. The way that Professor Dawkins discusses and, to my knowledge, trivializes eyesight and embryology, just two examples, amazes me. I wouldn’t have thought it possible. Forgive my presumed delusions but the biochemistry, for starters, behind a “simple light sensitive patch,” unknown to Darwin, doesn’t look all that simple. Where would we start concerning embryology? It was good to see that Professor Dawkins saw the need to thin out probability assessments with regard to “both DNA and its protein-based replication machinery spontaneously chancing to come into existence,” spreading them across arbitrary assumptions of 100 billion billion earth-like planets - a tacit acknowledgement that it’s a doozy, incomprehensible good fortune. Earlier in the same book (The Blind Watchmaker), he assesses the probability of producing a hemoglobin molecule in a single step by chance, concluding, simply, that it would not be possible. Is RNA/DNA and its replication machinery somehow much simpler than hemoglobin? If so, can’t we just ratchet up our planet variable until hemoglobin appears? Professor Greene gives us an infinity of planets –no? To be clear, Professor Dawkins, however it happened, you are, in the case of RNA/DNA, asserting that, if not analogous to a flight ready 747, something preposterously complex appeared spontaneously which, in itself, is an immense distance from the simplest of life forms. Despite your strong and condescending language, your readers have every right and very good reason to chew on whether this is within the reasonable productive boundaries of purely accidental expressions of natural law on any earth-like planet, no matter their number. After RNA and cumulative selection get going, “we need to postulate only a relatively small amount of luck in the subsequent evolution of life and intelligence.” Honestly? Why would Stephen Gould worry about the “astounding cascades of improbability” as a defining aspect of “the remarkable construction and operation of organisms,” even after the doozy? Was he not aware of cumulative selection? I can’t imagine him quipping that eyes evolved “easily, at the drop of a hat.” In the same vein, I recently watched a Book-TV and another interview with Bill Nye the Science Guy who, evidently, is influential with young people and has also written a book. He seemed pained that people who think there’s something special about conscious life on earth haven’t yet been eliminated from the gene pool, and seeks to at least reeducate them. He was very good at using trendy vernacular to hammer away that the earth isn’t 6,000 years old as he seems to think people who dare still have questions about the emergence and evolution of life believe. Over more than 20 years of immersive interest, I have never met or read anybody who believes that. Nor have I met or read anybody who doubts that life evolved, until now. I’ve attended a couple of lectures featuring Kenneth Miller who continues to get a kick out of the proceedings of Kitzmiller v. Dover but never quite elucidates the issues nearly to the depth I’d expect. He may well have deeper reasoning, but why the reluctance to share it with audiences at Princeton University? I’m unsettled about inferences regarding Intelligent Design but as I listened to Professor Miller, admittedly I thought how Michael Denton, Michael Behe and Stephen Meyer warrant every ounce of this man’s attention, for the good of science. Just a few points pertinent to Professor Greene’s hammering in this regard:1)	Copernicus wrote his book 500 years ago. Since then, most of Professor Greene’s readership has come to grips with the idea that the universe is very big and we wee. 2)	From other sources, I’ve learned a lot more about the nearly inconceivable calibrations and workings of our segment of infinite space, of the earth and especially of life which, to my mind, are immune to demotion. Knowing the forces behind the Earth’s 5,974,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 kilogram revolution and rotation, 66,000mph and 1,100mph respectively, doesn’t make it any less spectacular that my coffee hasn’t flown all over the place. Conscious life presents a vastly more undemotable kettle of fish. Whereas we understand that prospects for infinitely large (collections of) universes make every possible particle arrangement, dead or alive, equally probable and inevitable, Professor Greene and Mr. Nye might forgive their readers, too, for thinking that there’s something qualitatively notable about particle arrangements that walk and think and talk. 3)	Truth be told, the thought that I have a parallel some10 to the 10**122th meters away doesn’t feel like a demotion.4)	Cosmic demotion is a kind of isolationist my-dad-is-bigger-than-your-dad argument. Why would we not be thrilled that there are infinite conscious beings wondering whether there are infinite conscious beings? I rather like other conscious beings – it would be tragic if we were alone in that privilege.  Professor Greene declares his “bias” early in the book: “I believe that a physical system is completely determined by the arrangements of its particles. Tell me how the particles making up the earth, the sun, the galaxy, and everything else are arranged and you’ve fully articulated reality. This reductionist view is common among physicists, but there are certainly people who think otherwise. Especially when it comes to life, some believe that an essential nonphysical aspect (spirit, soul, life force, chi and so on) is required to animate the physical. Although I remain open to this possibility, I’ve never encountered any evidence to support it. The position that makes the most sense to me is that one’s physical and mental characteristics are nothing but a manifestation of how the particles in one’s body are arranged….. Every decision you’ve ever made is tantamount to a particular particle arrangement…..”Fair enough. But then towards the end of the book we’re treated to the “high likelihood that we’re living in a computer simulation” built by someone who “can come home at night, kick back and fire up the create-a-universe software” on an earth-size (quantum) computer. What happened between pages 38 and 330 that the need to “encounter evidence” disappeared? How did we get to “high likelihood,” and “odds that overwhelmingly favor the conclusion that you and I and everyone else are living within a simulation?” Oh wait, Oxford philosopher Nick Bostrom said so based on statistical projections which are based on baseless conjecture of what future, super-evolved hobbyists will choose to do with their time and presumed capability. Playthings, we are.  Wouldn’t you know it! Puny for sure, but now, just when I’m plum out of eyebrows, there’s a high likelihood that we’re not even real. That, my friends, would spell demotion. I stewed a long time in college over whether I was in a coma and other kinds of deep thinking deriving from Solipsism. Then I decided that it was both callous and disrespectful to deny the reality of so much human sacrifice and suffering past, present and future - I can’t imagine Professors Bostrom and Greene suggesting that the three year old refugee face down on a beach wasn’t and isn’t real. That was even before my frontal lobe caught up with the rest of me and it all became a lot of self-focused nonsense. Turns out that the stark and evidential realities of protein manufacture, photosynthesis and field theory alone beat the deep thinking pants off of coma suppositions, and simulations. Professor Greene is just wrong and silly in his evidence-free and callous declarations, but that isn’t the alarming part. With his premise that every possible particle arrangement is necessarily realized (infinitely), is it not decidedly and astonishingly unimaginative to settle and spend so much time on an image as earthly and everyday as a computer jock kicking back to boot up our sentient virtual existence? What about prospects for other renderings of superior, creative intelligences in this world of infinite inevitability (not in human or computer jock form), the size of the earth or a galaxy, let’s say. What would its creative capability be? For me, things became comical when Professor Greene suggested that the omnipotent computer geek might someday reveal himself through your bathroom window or “on a worldwide scale, with giant windows and a booming voice surrounding the planet, announcing that there is in fact an All Powerful Programmer up in the heavens.” Where have I heard that before…..to Professor Dawkins’ and Greene’s dismissal if not distain? It’s mildly interesting that in Climbing Mount Improbable, Professor Dawkins reasons that “…..any designer capable of constructing the dazzling array of living things would have to be intelligent and complicated beyond all imagining…..” Intelligent and complicated indeed, but not too intelligent and complicated for the likes of a computer programmer it would seem. Perhaps Professors Dawkins and Greene should do coffee. Moreover, isn’t the very core of faith the (self-demoting) notion that there exists a creative intelligence beyond our own? Lest we inexplicably confine ourselves to earth-bound, anthropomorphic images, it would seem that nothing in Professor Greene’s thesis precludes such a notion and, in fact, may well affirm it unequivocally. I would never make that argument, of course, but Professor Greene does, however inadvertently. Beyond this, however, we must understand that according to Professor Greene’s assertions, there is no need for an “all powerful programmer” or intelligence of any kind. Infinite universes will exist where exceedingly large and sophisticated computers producing simulated universes will simply have appeared chugging along without an inventor. Real, sentient, intelligent beings will be completely unknown to the real universes in which such computers happen to simulate humans. As well, infinite real (and simulated) universes will exist containing all of the inventions, constructions and events that we normally associate with and attribute to human ingenuity, effort and activity, except that life will not exist in them. For no purpose, all of the computers will run precisely as they do on this earth, every written sentence will chance into parallel bindings, every work of artistic expression framed, fastened or pressed, planes will fly, cars will drive, cities will arise absent only human life . Infinite worlds will exist where all of the objects in such people-free parallels will be upside down. My guess is that upside down cars won’t drive, but that’s none of our affair? In infinite universes, they’ll skid along on their roofs as a matter of random, moment-by-moment particle rearrangement and fortuitous reconstitution. All manner of weirdness animates the inanimate in every imaginable and unimaginable way. Senseless and meaningless - perfect. The workings of RNA and DNA and flight ready Boeing 747s smack of underachievement. The whole of natural and human history a dithering yawn. Rational assessment ceases. Fantasy loses its meaning. Nihilism triumphs. I’m not sure where notions of self- organizing complexity have gone but, to be clear, this is the underlying scientific reasoning upon which Professor Dawkins finds the rest of us delusional, Bill Nye suffers our ignorance and Professor Miller continues to have lots of fun. As I continue to more independently think about the hairbrained implications of Professor Greene’s thesis, implications that he omits either as a matter of anemic imagination or to maintain some semblance of credibility and sanity, I’m afraid that my mind invariably returns to that particle arrangement on the beach.Even less starkly, and for all the good this educator has done, pity the young mind in Professor Greene’s grip that “fully articulates” Beethoven’s 9th as a particle arrangement or attributes the deepening mysteries of life, the night sky, the love of his/her life and Dachau to a computer simulation. Pity the nation whose educational foundation goes so easy. Pity the professor, celebrity or otherwise, who waxes cavalier about the most finely orchestrated complexities and realities known to man, realities that, ironically, will continue to so effortlessly elude even his extraordinary intellect. I don’t know anything about chi or virgin births either but in the expanse of so much erudite wrangling I did find Mary Roach’s conclusion of Gulp (involving a close and entertaining look at the digestive system, end-to-end) haltingly accessible and instructive: 	“There is an unnameable feeling I’ve had maybe ten times in my life. It is a mix of wonder, privilege, humility. An awe that borders on fear. I’ve felt it in a field of snow on the outskirts of Fairbanks, Alaska, with the northern lights whipping overhead so seemingly close I dropped to my knees. I am walloped by it on dark nights in the mountains, looking up at the sparkling smear of our galaxy. Laying eyes on my own ileocecal valve, peering into my appendix from within, bearing witness to the magnificent complexity of the human body, I felt, let’s be honest, mild to moderate cramping. But you understand what I’m getting at here. Most of us pass our lives never once laying eyes on our organs, the most precious and amazing things we own. Until something goes wrong, we barely give them thought. This seems strange to me. How is it that we find Christina Aguilera more interesting than the inside of our own bodies? It is, of course, possible that I seem strange. You may be thinking, Wow, that Mary Roach has her head up her ass. To which I say: Only briefly, and with the utmost respect.”	She may not agree with even one of my sentences but, if nothing else, approximations and perspectives like Mary Roach’s seeping into scientific parley might temper our fixation on social media, better alert young people to the dimensional boundlessness of scientific inquiry, and make conscious beings harder to shoot. If you’re seeking engaging and recent books on physics written for adults, you might give The Particle at the End of the Universe and Life on the Edge a look.

Brian Greene compares, contrasts, nests and branes the set of 11 distinct multiverse proposals currently accepted as possible (dating up to the publishing date of 2011). He does this clearly with healthy portions of detail. My single complaint stems over his brief and inevitable anecdotal use of the double-slit experiment. And take this how you will. My knowledge of physics goes as far as personal reading plus my dad's personal obsession with the subject. Many people call attention to the double-slit experiment and its most widely-known cousin, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, in order to conjure some hand-waving aura of generalized trippiness about the nature of quantum mechanics (e.g. WHEN YOU LOOK AT IT, IT ACTS DIFFERENT, DUDE...LIKE WTF--or something along those lines). This can be fun, though I'll add there are better ways to get there than conjecture about quantum mechanics.Such a statement suffers from differing uses of the word 'look.' Electrons observed in the experiment do indeed behave differently when you 'look' at them compared to when you don't. However, 'look,' in this case, means to bounce (loads) of photons off of the electrons you are observing. In my experience, perhaps 95% of the time this 'quantum weirdness' is invoked, by published media, no less your friend at the party, this process of interaction with the measured electrons in question is totally missed.Greene, when using this experiment to explain probability waves, eventually comes to say this:When you look at an electron’s probability wave, where “look” means “measure its position,” the electron responds by snapping to attention and coalescing at one definite location. Correspondingly, the probability wave surges to 100 percent at that spot, while collapsing to 0 percent everywhere else, as in Figure 8.6. Look away, and the needle-thin probability wave rapidly spreads, indicating that once again there’s a reasonable chance of finding the electron at a variety of locations.Greene, Brian. The Hidden Reality: Parallel Universes and the Deep Laws of the Cosmos (Kindle Locations 3779-3782). Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group. Kindle Edition. For me, this is still too abstract to really get it, concerning the measurement interaction. Far better than terminology of electrons "knowing" where other electrons are--which Greene also uses, with the quotation marks--but for me it just didn't quite click. It would have only taken a paragraph more to get across the interaction between photons and electrons, which I feel is far more concrete. In any case, the statement of this phenomenon which I understood best was given in Richard Feynman's Six Easy Pieces, chapter six. I read it days before coming across Greene's account, which unfortunately increased the bloated irritation you see here. What are you doing still reading?This surely qualifies as nitpicking. And worse, I haven't read any of Greene's other work yet. He may get into this with greater detail in The Fabric of the Cosmos. I picked up The Hidden Reality after seeing Greene's visual explanation of gravitational waves on Colbert back in 2016, which remains the best I've come across yet. This is a great primer on multiverses, as far as I'm concerned. Greene is clear about the content, the history and the general current consensus for each proposal, and makes sure you know when he is expressing his personal intuitions and hopes for a given theory.

The Hidden Reality is a layman's primer on the latest in theoretical physics, structured around the ways in which recent theories suggest that our universe may be only one of many. It takes the reader on a tour of Einsteinian relativity, quantum mechanics, and, most particularly, string theory.The book unveils its physics through the presentation of several potential conclusions that flow from current theories about our universe, often ideas that attempt to reconcile Einstein’s theory of gravity and curved spacetime with the uncertainties of quantum physics. Each of these conclusions posits one way in which our universe might be part of a greater multiverse. The first of these is the “quilted multiverse,” which is simply a way of describing the consequences of infinity. If our universe is infinite, but the number of states in individual sectors of that universe are finite, then those states will necessarily repeat, yielding regions that are identical or nearly so. So there would be infinite earths, and nearly-earths, and infinite yous and nearly-yous. The second is the “inflationary multiverse,” and its variant, the “landscape multiverse,” in which universes drop like bubbles out of a substrate of inflation particles, and then further universes drop like further bubbles from those universes, yielding many universes with differing initial states and physical constants. The third is the “brane multiverse,” which posits that our three-dimensional universe sits on a membrane in a larger multidimensional space that could be filled with other three-dimensional universes. When these universes collide, they may create new big bangs, which lead to new universes over time, in a so-called “cyclic multiverse.” The fourth is the “quantum multiverse,” in which all possible quantum states are given reality through divergent parallel universes. The fifth is the “holographic multiverse,” which emerges from the fact that the mathematics of our universe can be modeled as though taking place on a boundary surface of our universe; if this boundary surface is real, it would constitute an equivalent parallel universe. The sixth is the “simulated multiverse,” which suggests that if intelligent life can attain sufficient technological skill to create realistic simulated universes, those universes may be more numerous than root universes, making it more likely we exist in a simulated universe than a real one. The seventh is the “ultimate multiverse,” which is just a way of describing the idea that all possible universes are real.As may be inferred from the above descriptions, the potential multiverse ideas progress from those more closely grounded in our physical and mathematical understanding of the universe to those that are more purely philosophical in nature. Brian Greene is a skilled writer and teacher, and he’s crafted a clever way to satisfy readers of all levels of mathematical sophistication. He opens chapters with conceptual descriptions using real-world analogies, and saves a deeper dive into the physics and math to the ends of chapters and the footnotes. This allows readers to calibrate their level of engagement to their mathematical background. Moreover, Greene’s excitement over the ideas discussed and for the scientific process of discovery shines through every chapter. The reader is caught up and carried along by this enthusiasm, and the revelations and ideas are fascinating to absorb and behold. Even beside the parallel universe framework, the book effectively conveys key concepts of mainstream physics and string theory, threaded with interesting tidbits of scientific history; I significantly enhanced my understanding of probability waves and several other phenomena.Occasionally, explanations could be slowed down. For example, there’s not enough discourse on why a bubble universe may appear to be infinite in time from the outside, but infinite in space from the inside. Moreover, as Greene acknowledges, the thesis of the book depends on taking a realist view of mathematics, rather than an instrumentalist view; while Greene touches on why he subscribes to the realist view, since the idea is a critical assumption of the book, more time could be devoted to convincing the reader. And much as Greene tries, I was still left with skepticism about the direction of string theory research because it's not generating reasonably testable hypotheses.Overall, I was intrigued and entertained throughout, and many times paused, book in hand, to contemplate the ideas presented and the vastness that the universe encompasses. This is a rare science book that engages both mind and heart. I enjoyed Greene’s The Elegant Universe, but found this one even more captivating.

Arthur C Clarke is often quoted as saying "the Universe is not only stranger than we imagine, it is stranger than we can imagine". This book puts that quote to a strong test, because it demonstrates the extreme outer limits of what one "can imagine".It's not enough that we may live in a multiverse. There are multiple multiverse proposals to choose from, and some of them may overlap with each other. Greene goes through the variants:- the Quilted Multiverse, where space, having the same laws of physics that we see, is infinite in extent and therefore contains all possible configurations of particles, each infinite times over (because infinity is very large, especially towards the end)- the Inflationary Multiverse: posits "bubble universes" generated by an "inflaton field", each having potentially different fundamental constants of nature. (this one is truly head-spinning, because "the math says" we might one day be able to create a real universe out of only a few grams-worth of energy: relying on inflation, which is negative gravity, to spontaneously generate a universe-worth of matter and energy. As Paul Davies has written, "The Universe could be the ultimate free lunch." The bad news is we wouldn't be able to interact with our creation.)- The "brane" multiverse of string theory. Too difficult to articulate; involves the ten spatial dimensions (!) that string theory math requires- The "many worlds" interpretation of quantum mechanics. This is the one with which I have the most familiarity from past reading; it was first proposed by Hugh Everett as an interpretation of the famous Schroedinger equations. To put a finer point on it, Greene returns several times to the fact that "the math" doesn't need to be "interpreted"; it merely needs to be taken seriously. In the final chapter Greene recounts multiple famous examples of scientists failing to take "the math" seriously: famously, Einstein's general relativity equations predicted both black holes and an expanding universe, neither of which he or anyone else took seriously until empirical observations forced the issue. Earlier, Maxwell's equations had predicted the speed of light as being a constant, but it took Einstein to truly take it seriously as being independent of any referent.- The holographic multiverse- The simulated multiverse and the ultimate multiverseI listened to the audiobook version which was actually narrated by Brian Greene himself, which I find amazing. Greene gives quite a sympathetic hearing to the criticism that, because many of these multiverse proposals are untestable, they "are not science." (This review was originally posted on my blog at damianroache.com)Brian Greene is a very intelligent guy, an accomplished physicist and mathematician, and he also happens to be a hell of a writer. In The Hidden Reality: Parallel Universes and the Deep Laws of the Cosmos he deftly guides us through some of the amazingly complex ideas and scientific foundations behind the popularized notion of the multiverse. His explanation of the core concepts at work are thorough, but not laden with excessive technical language or the type of writing that demands a dictionary be kept close at hand. This is a boon to the vast majority of his potential readers, most of whom probably didn’t graduate from Harvard and Oxford, as he begins to talk about the potential for worlds that exist outside of our universe. Greene tackles a particularly murky and labyrinthine area of physics, but somehow distills all of the essential information into language that a non-scientist can digest. He does all of this while firmly grounding his discussions in the larger scientific paradigms which inform any talk of multiple universes.My own reading of the book was colored by my admittedly biased view of the topic (because I firmly believe that we are part of a multiverse) and by my desire to contextualize some of the ideas that frequently play a large role in my fiction writing. If I’m going to write about characters that cross over into other worlds and venture into realities that do not fit within our conventional model of a single universe, I need to at least understand some of the science underlying these fictional pursuits. I wanted to have a better idea of what it means when people talk about infinite space and the possibility of worlds beyond the range of our senses.The scope of possible topics within the text would appear to be limited by his focus on one particular set of theories, but after reading it all the way through I can safely say that this is not at all the case.Do you know how many different theories propose the idea of a multiverse? I didn’t have any idea how many there actually are until I read this book. Greene takes us on a tour of nine different theories, each of which has its own proposed set of features and logic to explain the existence of a multiverse. There’s the Quilted Multiverse, in which our world would be part of an infinitely large expanse where the conditions of reality are repeated over and over. The Inflationary Multiverse proposes that we might be part of an ever-expanding space that eternally continues to create bubble universes propelled ever-farther from each other. And the Quantum Multiverse seeks to show how there could be a parallel universe for every possibility inherent in the probability waves which make up a key component of quantum mechanics. That’s only a third of the different forms of multiverses Greene writes about, and already you can begin to see how dense—from a reader’s perspective, not in a literal, physical sense—the subject of parallel worlds is once you get into the details.I found this book on Amazon when I was searching for something to read that I could both enjoy and learn from—for me The Hidden Reality accomplished this to a degree I wouldn’t have guessed. There’s more to the book than a long series of scientific theories broken into their respective parts, because Greene goes a step further to show some of the practical applications—and consequences—of viewing our existence as part of a larger reality. For example, late in the book Greene goes into detail about the Simulated Multiverse in which technological advances reach a point where we have the capacity to simulate entire digital universes filled with simulated inhabitants capable of thought, who are also able to create such universes within their own. Once this idea is established in the mind of the reader, which takes some time and considerable effort, he then takes the idea of the Simulated Multiverse to its furthest logical extension: that it’s theoretically possible our universe is actually a simulation, created in some other realm and existing only as data that has no equivalent physical form tying it to reality. How would we know if that were the case, and what would it mean? Greene attempts to answer some of these questions throughout the text. It’s in these sections that the text becomes more than a mere ‘Idiots Guide to Parallel Worlds.’Of course, the information contained in The Hidden Reality is not as hidden as the supposed other worlds made possible by the theories it talks about. Greene’s purpose in writing the book was not to propose some new insight involving multiverses or theories advocating their existence. This text is meant to provide a strong basis of understanding for anyone looking to learn about multiverse theory and all it entails. In that sense, it’s a complete success. With a little determination and an open mind, most people could read this book and come away with a better understanding of how such amazing things as doppelgangers and higher dimensions could one day be considered scientific fact—no longer relegated to the domain of science-fiction. It’s important to note, however, that Greene is cautious in his approach and informs the reader of the healthy skepticism that many physicists have when talking about multiverses.If you have a background in science, this book probably won’t have much to offer for you. But if you’re an average reader, like myself, with only a basic knowledge of the subject and a desire to know more, this is a great place to start. I haven’t read other, similar books, but that’s on my to-do list. There are other scientist-authors venturing into the speculative territory of parallel worlds, and I’m curious to see how their work compares to Greene’s. Until then, what I can say for sure is that Brian Greene is a more than adequate source for learning the basics of the physics that are behind current theories of the multiverse.The final verdict on The Hidden Reality is that it’s an illuminating look into some very strange science, one that I think holds some appeal for anyone who’s willing to stretch their mind some. For writers that work in the genres of fantasy, science-fiction, and horror, I’d say this is a must-read—unless, again, you already have a working knowledge of the physics involved. I didn’t have a lot of experience with physics to use as a base for my stories, but I had the urge to find that base. I wasn’t looking for an ultimate, comprehensive source, but enough to say with some confidence that I do actually know what the hell I’m talking about. Having invested some time into learning more about the subject, I now feel better prepared to write stories that are built upon, and grapple with, the idea of multiple universes.As always, I know there’s still plenty left for me to learn—but I’m on the right track now, thanks to Brian Greene and his thoughtful, well-written tour of the science of multiverses.

I rated this book 4 stars, which means I consider this book to be exceptional but not classics (that's why I rarely give 5 stars- otherwise classics will not be called classics).This book is an exploration of the concept "parallel universe", defined very loosely by the author. Greene lays out 9 versions (some can be synthesized together, some are subsets of a higher level category) of parallel universe, summarized well by other GR reviewers.Things I like about this book：1. It is extremely accessible. Greene's use of analogies and his wit undoubtedly contribute to this. I have background in sciences (but mostly in chemistry and biology), and consider myself to be a reasonably intelligent person. Yet, I say to friends time to time that Physics (especially relativity, quantum and string theory) are for smart (really smart I mean) people. Greene did a great job in making this book readable to the general audience.2. I like how Greene unfolds the historical development of theories. It adds the story telling element to the book, brings me more scientific/historic context, and backs up Greene's philosophy that scientific breakthroughs, however novel they appear, build on ideas of previous generation.3. It's hard to find a balance between science (meat) and philosophy (wine, I would say) served in a book on this topic, but Greene does a fantastic job in it (of course, evaluated by my subjective opinion). I like his detour on statistics or probability can't be defined without invoking the concept of probability (a circular argument, in philosopher's term) and his touch on other philosophical views (scientific philosophy in last chapter, humanity in Quantum Multiverse etc). I enjoyed those pieces a lot.I will probably not touch another serious scientific writing on physics for a while. Yet, the other two books by Greene will definitely be among my considerations when I return some day in the future.

This book was not for me, way way way above my intellectual capacity. In all honesty, I did not read this book. I skipped parts of it because I am fascinated by theissues raised by the author. I simply do not have the energy to put into understanding a realforeign language of science and mathematics.However, my primary interest was in how the author could call his constructs science. The mathematics of physics is a measure, not as reality, and this is especially true when unlike experimental science, there has been no corroboration by repeated experiments. I suspect that by the nature of the study, multiple universes, etc, there cannot be.In a word, I wondered how what he says could be science. The author is honest enough to understand the criticism and spends a fair amount of time trying to meet the criticism. p. 163 Until now, we've been exploring the implications for reality, writ large, of various developments in fundamental physics and cosmology research. I delight in the possibility that copies of the earth exist in the far reaches of space, or that our universe is one of many bubbles in an inflating cosmos, or that we live on one of many braneworlds constituting a giant cosmic laof ...But with the Landscape Multiverse, we've invoked parallel universes in a different way .
