Instead, an array of parallel universes, worlds that may be beyond our ability to visit o see or test or influence, now and perhaps always, are directly invoked to provide insight into observations we make here, in this universe.Which raises an essential question: Is this science?

Brian Greene takes us on an interesting journey across the different parallel universes & multiverses that arise from different theories in physics. The multiverses that are discussed in this book are: Quilted Multiverse, Inflationary Multiverse, Brane Multiverse, Cyclic Multiverse, Landscape Multiverse, Quantum Multiverse, Holographic Multiverse, Simulated Multiverse, and Ultimate Multiverse. When discussing each multiverse, the author provides enough information and explains the relevant concepts in order to understand it. Additionally, the author provides notes at the end of the book that are mainly aimed at more technical readers to further explain a concept using technical terms and equations. Even further, the author references more advanced/technical books that should be read in order to fully grasp all the ins & outs of each multiverse if the readers seeks further details and technicality. As always, Greene uses everyday analogies and illustrations in order to explain difficult concepts and make them more accessible to the general reader, though some concepts are still hard to understand fully. This book was written as a standalone book, but a previous knowledge in physics theories (General relativity, quantum mechanics, string theory, etc.) will definitely help the reader throughout the book and make the reading more enjoyable. A good book to read before this is Greene’s book “The Fabric of the Cosmos” but is not absolutely required.

Once again Brian Greene does a terrific job explaining the often convoluted physics (both classical and quantum) as well as the complicated mathematics that go into the present-day theories of parallel universes and alternate realities. Like his previous works, Greene touches on a familiar story: how the cosmic microwave background radiation (that's a direct consequence of general relativity combined with basic cosmological physics, and is itself a modern remnant of the Big Bang) only came to prominence after being discovered twice theoretically (and a dozen years apart) before being randomly observed as techs attempted to install a satellite and couldn't understand why they couldn't achieve a clear signal (that pesky cosmic microwave interference!). Greene then surveys the various multiverse options, from bubble and quilted to simulated to holographic, and shows how scientists must "follow the math", no matter where it takes them. To this point, he references another famous story: how Einstein, in an effort to keep the universe static (as religious dogma and the world, at the time, staunchly believed) instead of inflating (which the math demonstrated in his own equation), leading Einstein to push against his own findings by inventing an integer to agree with his preconception: the cosmological constant. The truth can sometimes be terrifying, but it is always illuminating, and I'm thrilled to see where science takes us in the years to come.

Fantastic read - assuming you are into this sort of things. The first 3/4 of the book is extremely well organized, and fairly easy to follow. Each chapter seems to be organized as: background/history, intro to the math/science, how a theory of possible multiverse stems from the math/science. Often, the history, and science background is more interesting then the thoughts on possible multiverse that stems from the science. The last 1/4 of the book seems to deviate from that formula a bit, and is a harder read. While there is no actual math in the book, the last chapters delve deeper into speculation based on some pretty hard math. So sometimes I had to re-read sections, and sometimes I scratched my head, thinking the scientists had to be smoking something when they came up with these ideas. However, even though the last chapters made me work harder, it was still a worthwhile read. I have read a few books lately on quantum theory, string theory, and cosmology. Very often these books used allegories that were over simplified, or deeply flawed. Brian Greene did a much better job in explaining what can be very complex science, than many of the other books I have read. It's obvious that Mr. Greene both lives an breaths this stuff every day, and is well practiced at explaining it to laymen, as he both seems to know the topic well, and explains it well. Definitely not a book for everyone. But I enjoyed it.

I listened to the audio book edition of this book. The author is the reader, and he is a good reader. The book is about the possible scenarios for multiple, parallel universes offered up by modern physics research. His treatment of the subject is great. This is the kind of stuff I would have eaten up as a teenager. But by now my tastes have changed, and I am much more critical of it.A quote from the beginning of chapter 3: "For all its progress, string theory has yet to make definitive predictions whose experimental investigation could prove the theory right or wrong." So string theory does not even meet basic falsifiability criteria? Great.. Imagine an author like this making a statement like that in relation to homeopathy or clairvoyance, or even something like chi that has played a significant role in traditional Chinese medicine for over five thousand years?Here is what the author has to say about chi in this book: "Especially when it comes to life, some people believe that an essential nonphysical aspect (spirit, soul, life force, chi, and so on) is required to animate the physical. Although I remain open to this possibility, I've never encountered any evidence to support it. The position that makes the most sense to me is that one's physical and mental characteristics are nothing but a manifestation of how the particles in one's body are arranged. Specify the particle arrangement and you've specified everything." So wait, have you ever encountered any evidence to support that last statement?Don't get me wrong - I think super-string theory is great stuff, and that people should be studying it. A little later in the book, the author does say that the theory is speculative, and discusses at some length why he thinks this is still science, and still valuable science. His arguments work for me. But I do still see a double-standard at play here. Lack of evidence, in regards to super-strings, or to chi, or to whatever else, is not a disproof. And lack of evidence can mean many things, including nobody really searching for evidence. For instance, how many billions of dollars per year are spent world wide on physics research, including basic research, telescopes, particle collidors, and supporting staff for all these endeavors? Just how many billions of dollars a year? If would be interesting to get an estimate. What would happen if you gave a competent administrator with an interest in tai chi and Chinese medicine, say, a hundred million dollars a year for a period of, say, 20 years, to study the phenomenon of chi? Just a tiny fraction of the budget for physics research. They may well turn up some real evidence for the phenomenon. And if they didn't, that would certainly be a valuable result as well. But it's just a thought-experiment, and will probably always stay that way, since there is virtually no chance that anybody will invest this kind of money in chi research in the current socio-political climate.Okay, I started with a long digression, so back to the book. The author does a great job of explaining highly complex and hard to understand concepts of modern physics in ways that are very accessible to a reader with little to no physics background. He is entertaining, and he evokes trust. He reads his own work, and is a good reader. The subject matter is also interesting - an exploration of the different possible ways that modern physics research supports the possibilities of multiple universes, or many worlds. Overall, it's a great treatment. But a few things bother me about it.My first complaint is a general one and certainly no fault of the author's. It seems to be quite difficult to read an introductory account of a highly specialized area as presented by a specialist. Because I am so uninformed in the field, I have to rely on what the author has to say about the matter far more than is comfortable for me. It's a single person, so I am clearly exposed to any of his personal biases. In this case, the author seems to be very professional, and careful about his biases and the biases of others, so I am not terribly concerned. But there are also the biases that permeate the field as a whole, which, from within the field, can sometimes be very hard to make out. Unfortunately, without at least a few semesters of coursework in the area, I am completely susceptible to these biases, and I am completely reliant on the author's account of the matters in question.My second complaint is that because modern physics is a very new and unsettled field, and highly speculative in a lot of ways, I often get the sneaking suspicion that the many-worlds variants described in the book will be completely warped, or replaced with entirely different kinds of many-worlds theories, within just a decade or two of further research. Just how relevant can these descriptions of many-worlds be in a field that is in such flux? I can deal with this problem by telling myself that the many-worlds theories presented are just stories, and instead of taking them as some kind of genuine account of specific truths, taking them as descriptive, in a sort of broad-brush way, of the kinds of conclusions that modern physics would lead us to.Finally, while reading this book I can't help but wondering just how relevant any of this material is? In most cases, the best we can hope for would be to prove that certain kinds of parallel worlds exist. But we will never be able to visit these worlds, or have any real sense of what they are like, aside from their overall physical properties. It's definitely interesting, but, billions of dollars of research interesting? Not really. Especially when I think of all the things that we could invest in understanding, right here in the real world. Such as our bodies, our chi, our emotions, and our psyche. In meditation, with practice, we can directly connect to parts of the universe that we are as yet unable to explore with the technologies and mathematics of physics. This is much more tangible and meaningful than some other world that we won't ever know much of anything about besides what the gravitational constant is, and whether they have electrons or positrons, or both.

This is the second book by Greene that I have attempted to digest, and, thanks to my fanatical reading habits in the last few months, more than last time, I was better prepared for certain theoretical concepts. In audible form, I'm guilty of being distracted by my surroundings when listening, but crossing mid-town Manhattan everyday in mid-winter I tried my best to absorb the startling and fascinating propositions for reality that Greene dressed down from their mathematical heights. In my studious listening I tried to imagine a reality that I am unequipped to fully understand. But I enjoy bending my own conceptual muscles to see if even this tiny brain can understand 4 dimensions, let alone 10. A few things are now clear thanks to Greene and others like Sean Carroll who write physics for the masses, reality is only real to those that live it, all other parallel existences own the properties of the possible, whether or not it exists for our experience. This makes thinking about the possible impossible very exciting.

This dive into the ideas of multiverse leaves you thinking for days on end of the different sciences that affect and are affected by the idea of multiverse. Multiverse is the idea (Many, including mtself, don't believe in it, but it is still infinitely amazing to think about) that for everything that could happen, there is a universe where the other outcome did happen. For example, if you flip a coin and it lands on heads, there is an alternate universe where that coin landed on tails. The average living organism makes 3.6*10^13 calculations per second. That, times the number of living organisms (5*10^39) is equal to how many alternate universes would be created per second (18 with 53 0's). That's per second! Most people would probably find this incredibly boring, but I, for one, am obsessed with this thought. The book dives so much deeper into the topic, and was incredibly interesting to me, earning 5 stars in my book.

That was a mind stretching book. Not only in the sense that it explained concepts far outside of our normal culture earthbound, but so many of the ideas are theoretical. These thoughts would only really come up in conversations about deep physics based conversations or activities, and thus are often strange. However, I was really excited to learn about concepts like inflationary cosmology, cosmic time, probability waves, and multiverses of various types (especially simulated multiverses). I by no means understand them deeply, but Greene does a really good job of putting these complex concepts into somewhat relatable examples. He excels at it actually. The best thing that I can say for the book is that it made me much more interested in the field of physics, and due to it, I will read much more widely on the topic. It also made me want to go back and rewatch the show Fringe a lot. Well done.

This was a great introduction into current scientific thought about all possible worlds that could exist. The beginning of the book gives world possibilities more founded in current state of science while as the book goes on, the theories get more and more “into the fringes of scientific theory” and finally the later theories are more into the realm of philosophy or thought experiment than science (if considering the definition of science to be what is or could possibly be empirically proven or demonstrated). Some people might be turned off by this but I was not. Science and philosophy have went hand in hand and philosophy and thought experiments do have uses for science...it gives science things to pursue, a direction. Greene is very careful when outlining whether a theory is testable, how it could be proven, and what would disprove each possible world theory. Essentially this book is touching on the edges of what science is able to grasp as it goes on, but it’s a very fun ride.

Like two previous books, Dr. Greene superbly explained the main topic of his book, which is various multiverse models from the latest investigation of theory in physics and mathematics. Although his explanation is mostly easy to be understood, there are some points that I think unnecessarily repeated through the book, namely the need to assess the theoretical claims with experiments/observations. Also there are habits of him to explain a simple concept with a long prelude and stories which I feel not really important. Take example when he explained the parallel universe as consequence of the interpretation of the wave functions in quantum mechanics. Overall, it is a fun book to read. It has this twists here and there that made you questioning whether is this still physics, philosophy or straight science fiction type thing. A must read for anyone interested in „crazy stuff“ predicted by physics.

It was quite a challenge to read about things that I have no background in, but I enjoyed following along as best I could with some of the cutting edge and revolutionary theories out there. I still don’t truly understand Einstein but I see how he changed physics forever. I don’t understand string theory but I see that it is revolutionizing so many aspects of science. What I really appreciate about this book is that it doesn’t try to be dogmatic. It talks about the theories of science. Too often we hear about the truths of science when there is actually much more uncertainty than many of us are comfortable with. I know it is strange but this book strengthened my faith that God is working in ways that man has yet to fully comprehend. The enlightenment did not define God and we haven’t either. God is still bigger than what we are able to understand and comprehend. To me He is the hidden reality.

On the one hand, I listened to this book on tape in my car over the course of a month, which in the fits and starts it was consumed, made for a somewhat disjointed read. On the other hand, this book is so far at the edge of what my brain can understand, that even if I had been reading it in a white room with nothing on the walls, instead of listening to it in a car going 70 miles an hour, I still don't think I would have understood everything. With that being said, Greene did a moderately good job of explaining pretty much the most complicated stuff known to humanity. I wish he had used more humor, but his analogies to things I knew about made it more understandable. My main gripe is that with most of the stuff I still don't understand it well enough to explain at a cocktail party conversation, which was my main impetus for getting the book to begin with.

After reading The Elegant Universe, which I highly recommend, I saw the audiobook of this title and purchased it. It then had to await a trip long enough to accommodate the reading. I enjoyed it as much as I did The Elegant Universe, but in hindsight I wish I had read the print version. There is much to ponder in both books, too much so to do while driving. The ability to pause, to reflect, to flip back to earlier sections, or to reread passages is, for me at least, necessary to a full appreciation of both.While I have been a physics aficionado since my youth, I do not profess to be talented enough at physics to fully appreciate or to ably critique string theory. That said, I still did not come away from this book as optimistic about its future or as satisfied with the many worlds and multiverses the theory allows as I think the author hoped I would.

I picked up a copy of this book ages ago but took my time getting around to reading it. Consequently, this book about cutting edge scientific theories ended up a little dated after less than a decade. The material mostly holds up, but every now and then it postulates the consequences of things that have happened since, like the verification of the existence of the Higgs Boson or gravitational waves. Likewise, the book devotes an entire section to the holographic universe concept which has been frequently plastered on the news for the last several years; that is, I've read quite a lot about the topic since I purchased the book.This is not a bad book! It's good for anyone who wants to learn about the scientific ideas motivating the theories of parallel universes (without all the math). I made a mistake by not reading it when I bought it.

This is a pause-to-return to library read, not a DNF read when I put it down about 30% of the way through.Dr. Greene asks, "Are there parallel universes? How would we know?" and his explanations are sort of pitched at the detail-oriented person who has a high school level background in science and not more. In some ways, I wanted him to get to the cool and "woo" stuff, but I appreciate how he spends his time explaining how theories are built, how we know what we know, and the decades and centuries of experimentation that lead us to a variety of kinds of conclusions, and what we don't know yet.Leave it to a scientist to make a fascinating topic boring via explanations that try to cram a lot of information into a short book, but hey, that's what scientists do and I appreciate it. I'll get my fix of science fiction elsewhere.

Another superb book by Greene. I haven't read his latest yet (though I eagerly await the opportunity). But this, his third, was just as fascinating and brilliantly executed as his first two. This one focuses on multiverses and parallel worlds, different varieties of which arise (in the sense of being more-or-less forced by the mathematics) in different areas of modern physics (inflationary physics, quantum mechanics, etc.) The jury's out on whether any of the 'hidden realities' Greene describes are, in fact, real. But Greene does a superb job (as ever) of describing why they may be real and of identifying the sorts of empirical observations/tests that could at least support such a hypothesis. A challenging, inspiring, and mind-expanding book. I loved it!

I have to confess that I didn’t grasp all of this book, but the parts I did were tantalising enough to merit four stars. For the first time the concepts of string theory and the brane multiverse became clearer, as did a few other concepts but there were other times I fell asleep (quite literally) trying to figure out what Greene was saying. As when he slips in this explanation in one of the footnotes: “The conformal group of symmetry transformations is infinite-dimensional, and this proves essential to ensuring that the perturbative quantum analysis of a moving string is mathematically consistent”. Dude, seriously? Still, a good read for those that love physics.

This book is a trip!While I'm certain that I don't buy into most of the hypotheses described in The Hidden Reality, the fact that such ideas can be arrived at through the vehicle of mathematics demonstrates that maths are more than just cold, unfeeling numbers. In the right hands, mathematics can be a versatile set of brushes with which an imaginative philosopher can paint awe inspiring pictures of the cosmos. Brian Green is just that kind of artist. Sometimes the things he writes about remind me ideas born of smoking way too much pot. In fact, I'd say Brian Greene and his colleagues provide us with living evidence that a person can get high on math.

This book reviews one of the trippiest aspects of modern physics- the idea of multiple (maybe infinite?) parallel universes. And rather than just describing what parallel universes would look like, Greene gives us 8 different scenarios for how they could exist, then takes us through the very well-grounded physics behind each. The physics he describes are cutting edge- inflatons, quantum mechanics, string theory, etc. But Greene does a great job of making the very, very complex physics and mathematics accessible through analogies and simple language. Some of the sections drag a little, but overall it's a smart, interesting look at a fascinating topic.

Very well laid out for the layman who cannot go through all the math of higher-level physics. I kept having similar thoughts over and over throughout this book having to do with religion. First, many of the theories/speculations were so similar to or could potentially explain many doctrines in my own religion. Second, Brian Greene goes on about how many of these theories and "so out there"and to stay with him and scientists have the duty to explore all possibilities, but many scientists refuse to even theorize the possibility of a God (which they cannot disprove or should not rule out). I wonder where scientific theory would go if truly all possibilities are considered equally.

This was an excellent review of the topic of parallel universes. As with all of Greene's books, this one is very readable for the general reader but also difficult enough that you may want to go back and read certain sections. It will also make you feel that you actually learned something. I didn't realize that there were so many different, largely unrelated versions of the multiverse idea, though in hindsight I think I have heard of all of them. Overall, great book and well-worth the read if you're interested in the topic.

I read this book in hopes of learning about the multiverse. Not only did I learn that there are 9(!) versions of multiverses, it is mind blowing that they are mathematically & logically derived.I’ve read a couple other books on cosmology, but I have to say Brian Greene is the best at simplifying extremely complex concepts. I had many “aha!” moments reading this book. My favorites being the measure problem, principle of fecundity, and brane/cyclical multiverse. I began reading this book - which was languishing in my Kindle for a while - just as the news of the (potential) clinching evidence for the Inflationary model of the Big Bang cosmology came out (the polarization in the Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation due to gravitational waves form the Big Bang). And it was just what the doctor ordered. As most readers interested in such topics, I was already somewhat familiar with many of the concepts that Greene discusses, but what he does very well in the book is that he assumes no specific scientific knowledge base, no physics or mathematics above high school is needed and takes the reader gradually step by step through the admittedly esoteric concepts that are on on the cutting edge of modern day physics.Chapter by chapter, we are on a journey through an increasingly expanded view of reality. Greene takes us step by step through each version of the parallel or multiple universe by describing how those ideas were motivated by developments within physics and how in most cases those developments had nothing initially to do with pursuing a hidden reality or parallel universes. He describes how ideas about solving one problem or another in modern physics, like resolving a paradox about black holes swallowing information (something not allowed by Quantum Physics), or trying to explain the "flatness" and uniformity of the 3 dimensional universe we observe led physicists inexorably towards concepts that unambiguously suggest that those ideas - if true - would inevitably also mean that there are hidden realities out there which are much more expansive that what we had traditionally considered "the Universe".The explanations of the underlying physics and the associated scientific efforts are very well described. Greene mixes in the historical developments within science and the evolution of the ideas themselves with accessible explanations of those ideas and how they related to the then current understanding of the Universe well to give an enjoyable read. The explanations of the difficult physics or mathematics ideas are well supported by diagrams and pictures and whenever warranted he takes his time developing the idea before plunging into what its implications are for the topic at hand. This allows the reader to come into the book with little to no prior knowledge which is great. And for those who do possess some inkling, it provides a good review and a fresh perspective as well as putting it into context with relation to how those ideas relate to the multiverse view of reality.Another great aspect of the book is that the author is very careful to highlight and demark what is currently known to be correct in terms of Physics verified by experiment and what is for now still in the realm of hypothesis, speculation and conjecture. In fact a significant portion of the book is dedicated to discussing the current status of various proposals like the Inflationary cosmology model or string "theory" (which doesn't yet deserve the status of a scientific "theory" like say General Relativity or the Standard Model of particle Physics because it has not been tested experimentally and so is nothing more than a bunch of very interesting and suggestive ideas, but cannot rightly be called a theory which in science has a "revered" place of something that has been exhaustively verified by experimental data). These discussion highlight the core of the scientific process - how no idea is sacred and the importance of checking one's proposals via experiments and observations. Without that, these are nothing more than curious symbols scribbled onto paper. A lot of discussion goes into what it would or should take for us to take the reality of these multiple or parallel universes seriously and to "believe" in them. What it means to be scientifically tested. In the subject of hidden realities this is by definition tricky because they are, well, hidden. So with perfect clarity, Greene makes it clear what we currently think can and cannot be experimentally tested and how our ideas have now come to a place where even thinking about how to go about testing them stretches the imagination. It could very well be that we may never be sure in a scientific sense about the reality of some of the implications of these proposals because they might, even in principle, be untestable. This leads to a lot of deep question about what science can actually tell us about reality and how we could find ingenious ways to test the most outlandish ideas about the nature of our existence.All in all, the book is a great read to anyone who is interested in the deep questions about existence and wants to get the scientific low down about it. The language is flowing and the explanations accessible. Without presuming any deep knowledge of physics, the book manages to go very deep into the most interesting questions out there which everyone undoubtedly asks in one form or another at some point in their lives. It gives a thorough scientific view of these questions leaving the reader amazed about how far we have come in so short a time but also gives a glimpse into how far we might still have left to go. There are interesting discussions about the nature of scientific fact that arise naturally and are dealt with in appropriate clarity.So to anyone who is looking to expand their mind to the almost unfathomable wonder of the cosmos and our place in it, this book is a must read!

In this well-written book designed for a general audience, Brian Greene discusses string theory and hypothetical multiverse proposals. In dealing with string theory, he compares it to relativity, which deals with macroscopic phenomena such as gravity, and quantum mechanics, which deals with microscopic phenomena such as strong and weak nuclear forces. If relativity is used to evaluate microscopic phenomena or quantum mechanics is used to evaluate macroscopic phenomena, the math breaks down. Furthermore, the math of either method breaks down in dealing with singularities. String theory, on the other hand, can handle singularities, and string theory math simplifies to quantum mechanics when applied to microscopic phenomena and relativity when applied to macroscopic phenomena. For this reason, string theory appears promising although it is not testable with current technology.The following multiverse proposals are discussed in this book:- Quilted multiverse theory treats space as infinite such that there are regions of space that are too far apart to interact. The different non-interacting patches (zones or regions) are collectively called the quilted multiverse.- Inflationary multiverse theory incorporates inflationary cosmology, which modifies big bang theory by inserting an intense burst of enormously fast expansion during the universe’s earliest moments. The inflationary multiverse results when bubble universes continually form within an ever expanding spatial environment permeated by a high-valued inflaton field. Theoretically the inflaton field would not be uniform; rather there would be peaks and valleys. Regions of high field energy would generate repulsive gravity and inflation, generating bubble universes.- Brane multiverse theory utilizes two-dimensional objects, membranes, instead of the one-dimensional objects of string theory. These methods identify objects with up to ten spatial dimensions. Factoring in time as a dimension, there are eleven dimensions. The Brane multiverse implies multiverse separation across dimensions.- The cyclic multiverse is a variant of the brane multiverse accounting for the destruction by collision and regeneration of brane multiverses. Its appeal is its apparent ability to avoid the issue of how the universe began although the second law of thermodynamics is the monkey wrench in the works. As each iteration would produce increasing entropy, earlier cycles would have less entropy and would have had shorter durations. Sufficiently far back in time, the cycles would have been so short as to have ceased. There would still have been an ultimate beginning.- The landscape multiverse combines inflationary cosmology and string theory by positing that eternal inflation sprinkles string theory’s 10^500 possible forms for the extra dimensions across the bubble universes, one form for the extra dimensions per bubble universe. We just happen to live in the bubble whose extra dimensions yield a universe that is hospitable to our form of life and whose properties agree with observations.- Quantum multiverse theory proposes that all possible outcomes are realized as alternate realities in separate worlds. Although Dr. Greene does not mention this in the book, this multiverse proposal was popularized in an episode of Star Trek: The Next Generation.- Holographic multiverse theory posits that the universe is an information processor that takes information representing the here and now and produces information describing how it will change. The observable physical environment arises from this information and evolves according the laws of physics. It would be quite interesting to compare holographic multiverse theory with William Dembski's information metaphysics in Being As Communion.- There are two possible simulated multiverse options: creation of a real universe or a virtual universe. The first option would require at a minimum an inflaton field along with a white hole to start the process. Given that both phenomena are merely theoretical and have never been observed, this option is a tall order. The second option is essentially a computer simulation that utilizes advanced artificial intelligence technology to anticipate and appropriately respond to the mental states and intentions of its simulated inhabitants.- Finally, an ultimate universe is an all-encompassing multiverse in which all possible mathematical equations are realized physically. In other words, it fails to accept any possible hypothetical multiverse as brute-force reality. I haven't yet decided if it is a way to keep options open or if it is a merger of post-modern philosophy and cosmology.For the record, I do not accept multiverse theory but appreciate Dr. Greene's masterful communication skills and his ability to make arcane topics understandable for the layman.

I’ve become fascinated by quantum physics over the past several years. That isn’t to say that I understand it all that well, but I try. This is the fourth book I’ve read on the topic and, as I’ve become accustomed to with regards to this subject, it dropped my jaw more than a few times. The book is about what physicists are learning regarding the possibility of parallel/multiple universes. You have to read the book to get the full “knock you out of your chair” effect (not to mention the whys and hows), but here is a summary of the main “multiverse” theories that physicists believe, based on current scientific understanding, may exist:1) Quilted Multiverse: if our universe is infinite (and that - so far - is undetermined) then because there is only a finite number of ways in which particles can arrange themselves, there must be an infinite number of exact replicas of our part of the universe spread throughout the infinite universe. Though they are likely to be at distances far beyond anything we can observe or communicate with, in an infinite universe there are infinite numbers of Earths and Ryan Hunter’s writing book reviews.2) Inflationary Multiverse: think of all that there is as being an infinitely large and rapidly expanding slice of swiss cheese. The holes in the swiss cheese are universes, one of which is ours. At any moment, a new hole – or universe – could be created. Also, the cheese separating two holes could separate, combining the two holes (i.e. - a collision between two universes).3) Brane Multiverse: think of our universe as a three dimensional (+ time) slice of bread (i.e. a “brane”) and each additional slice as a different universe that together make up a ten dimensional cosmic loaf (though there is no limit on the number of slices in the loaf). Nothing can interact between the bread slice universes except for gravity (which is why gravity is so weak compared to other forces because it is diluted by its presence in the ten dimensions outside our universe).4) Cyclic Multiverse: This is an addition to the Brane Multiverse scenario in which two universes (slices of bread) collide with each other and then bounce off each other (i.e. the big bang), only to be pulled back toward each other by gravity in a pattern that repeats itself (though the whole time our universe continues to expand). Physicists estimate that this may occur on a 1 trillion year cycle. Our universe is 14 billion years old, so if this idea is correct, we have another 86 billion years before the next collision and big bang.5) Landscape Multiverse: This one is hard for me to describe, but the idea is that new universes may be formed within regions of our own universe, essentially bubbling up from empty space due to “quantum tunneling” (though we wouldn’t be able to perceive them as they would have different laws of physics and be entirely separate universes).6) Quantum Multiverse: Due to the quantum wave function - which tells us that a particle is in any of a number of locations at the same time but only locks in at one location when it is observed - all possible events actually happen in parallel universes and we only experience one of those events in our universe. To dramatize this idea, let’s say you were in a fender bender on your drive home because you rolled through a stop sign. There is a parallel universe where you did not roll through the stop sign and did not get in the wreck (since we are all made of particles, and because any one particle can be in numerous locations at once, so can we, and we only perceive one version of that reality). There is also a universe where you weren’t at the stop sign because you worked late that day. There is also a universe where you don’t exist because your parents never met. And there are an infinite number of other universes where any possible event or combination of events has occurred.7) Holographic Multiverse: Another hard one to describe, but the idea is that our universe is a three dimensional holographic projection of activity occurring on a two dimensional surface (and the activity has no resemblance to what it is represented by in our universe….for example, a black hole in our universe is simply a projection of a collection of hot particles on the two dimensional surface).These summaries do not do the subject justice. I highly recommend that you read the book, or any other book by Brian Greene, or any book by Michio Kaku, or Lisa Randall’s book “Warped Passages,” all of which deal with the amazing reality being discovered through quantum physics.

No Road Untraveled.This challenging, but fascinating, book from Brian Greene is another winner. It turns out that there's not just one version of the multiverse proposal but several, ranging from the Quilted and Inflationary Multiverses to the Brane and Quantum Multiverses. If you'r not careful you could get lost on this mathematical road trip. Drawing on everyday analogues to help explain the various examples of the Multiverse, Greene delves into the mysteries of Quantum Mechanics and Relativity searching for some common ground. As always his writing is geared for the well-read layperson but it helps to have a good background in reading this type of book. If you've read his previous books or similar titles by other authors then this one shouldn't be much of a problem. The whole idea of the Multiverse is based on extreme mathematics but you don't have to be a math wizard to enjoy the book. While the approach is non mathematical Greene does provide some equations (in the notes) for anybody so inclined. Some of the information is given as a kind of "refresher course" in String Theory and Quantum Mechanics but the author gives you the opportunity skip ahead if you wish to. Not being a physicists myself I tend to appreciate that kind of approach. The book is presented in 11 chapters with each chapter devoted to one or two kinds of Multiverse so the reader gets an in depth look at each variety. I found that some chapters were easier to read than others and there were some sections that were a little overwhelming in content. It took me two passes to read The Elegant Universe and three attempts on The Hidden Reality but in the end I got through both of them. I liked the section on the Inflationary Multiverse and it's "Swiss Cheese" analogy, it was the easiest to get through while the section on Quantum Mechanics, Probability Waves and Entropy was the most difficult. A good portion of the book is devoted to the history of theoretical physics and multiverse scenarios, giving you a look at the important people and events that made the most impact. To some people things like String Theory and Multiverses are more of a philosophy than a science since proof of their existence lies beyond our currant technology to access. To that end, the book closes with a section of extreme speculation on the future of computer simulation, artificial intelligence and the Multiverse. Read at your own risk. Scientist the world over are pushing the boundaries of knowledge with mathematics and observations, as well as complicated experiments but, so far, have not been unable to come up with any defining answers. And if the answers are not there or they lead in a different direction, then we will have to come up with a whole new set of metaphors to explain the world around us. The Hidden Reality gives you a well written glimpse at this strange landscape. But keep in mind that neither Greene or anyone else know for certain whether or not there are indeed Multiverses out there and he's the first one to admit that. Theoretical Physics is an active, fast changing field and researchers like Greene will continue probing the fringes of the known universe, looking for a way to combine electromagnetism and gravity into one coherent theory and also looking for the back door into other worlds and universes that may be lurking just out of sight, in some hidden reality. I recommend this book to any science reader who has an open, but skeptical, mind. This book focuses on the description of various scientific and philosophical trains of argument which lead to "parallel universes" or a "multiverse". Like Brian Greene's earlier books, The Elegant Universe and The Fabric of the Cosmos, it is full of interesting ideas; but I was not as impressed by this one. Where those books each followed out a single line of development wherever it seemed to lead (although for Greene it always seemed to lead to string theory), this book begins with a conclusion and then looks for all the many different possible arguments which might lead to it; and given the nature of the conclusion (the Multiverse) it has the feel of a "gosh-wow" book, concentrating on just those aspects of contemporary physics that seem counter-intuitive or astonishing and leaving out everything else -- I felt at times I was reading a book by Michio Kaku rather than Brian Greene.The arguments were uneven and did not seem all that convincing. Perhaps it was just that having recently read the more mathematical books by Penrose and Susskind I am more critical or at least less accepting of the simple analogies; but I just didn't think they "worked" as well as in the earlier books. For instance, he argues in the first chapter that if the universe is infinite and there are finitely many possible patterns of particles, each and every pattern must repeat exactly infinitely many times -- infinitely many Earths and infinitely many Brian Greenes writing infinitely many books . . . He uses the example of Imelda's shoes and outfits. (The reader under fifty may not get the allusion.) Eventually, if the number of outfits is finite, in infinite time (or infinite space) Imelda has to repeat her outfits. But it may as well be that she keeps wearing the last outfit, or chooses her outfits among the ones that had the most impact the first time she wore them, and avoids the horrible combination she vowed never to wear again. (One could imagine physical equivalents.) So the analogy doesn't prove that any combination must repeat infinitely many times, or even once. (Whatever may be the case with the particles.) The second analogy, with decks of cards, is based on an example where the probabilities are all equal, which begs the question. There are just too many cases like this throughout the book, where he may be right but his analogies don't support the conclusion.It may also be that while in the earlier books, he begins with accepted theories like quantum mechanics and general relativity and works up to the more speculative ideas like string theory, here he starts with speculative ideas from the beginning and ends up with more speculative metaphysics than physics. (Having majored in philosophy, I have no problem with a philosophical discussion of metaphysics, but physics and metaphysics are two different things, and if one wants to cross the boundaries, one needs to take into account the current technical arguments from both fields, not just combine modern advanced physics with Plato or a first year philosophy class.)The biggest problem, though, was that there just didn't seem to be all that much new here, except for the chapter on how string theory might be related to the cosmological constant (and even then, the cosmological constant just seems to replace other constants from earlier arguments.) If you've read his earlier books, and a few other recent popular books (Susskind's The Black Hole War and The Cosmic Landscape or Carroll's From Eternity to Here for example) there's no real reason to read this one. On the other hand, if this is the first book you've read on the subject you probably wouldn't follow it.
I'm not smart enough to even begin to understand the non-mathematical side of this.

Overview: An excellent primer on the various current theories of possible multiple universes and explanations of how they have arisen through scientific, mathematic, and psychological principles.In More DetailIf you enjoy reading books that try to explain science on a layman's level, then you might want to consider this book. Especially, if you have a fairly basic understanding of physics and/or have read other significant books in this genre such as Stephen Hawking's excellent book A Brief History of Time If you would like to get your feet wet in the understanding of the physics of the universe, but don't have any current knowledge, then I would recommend starting there first.This book covers a LOT of ground. I consider myself fairly well versed in physics in a broader sense having always found that science quite interesting. Even following the field to some degree, it's easy to get "behind." The Hidden Reality really did an excellent job of capturing my interest and discussing the topic at hand: multiple universe (multiverse) theories.Most of us have some idea of "parallel universes" based on science fiction television/movies or books. But this book covers 7 wildly different multiverse theories: The Quilted Multiverse, Inflationary Multiverse, Brane Multiverse, Cyclic Multiverse, Landscape Multiverse, Quantum Multiverse, Holographic Multiverse, Simulated Multiverse, and the Ultimate Multiverse. I knew of the existence of several of these theories, but none to the level of detail that I learned in the book.Even if you have little understanding of physics, Greene does spend several chapters giving a basic rundown of the physics involved or required for the understanding of several of these. I found these chapters to be quite interesting and worthwhile, for the most part. These specific chapters explain in basic language (and without any math required) classical mechanics, relativity, string theory (several different string theories, actually), Inference and Quantum Probability.More Like ThisA Brief History of Time by Stephen HawkingHyperspace: A Scientific Odyssey Through Parallel Universes, Time Warps, and the Tenth Dimension by Michio KakuParallel Worlds: A Journey Through Creation, Higher Dimensions, and the Future of the Cosmos by Michio KakuBlack Bodies and Quantum Cats: Tales from the Annals of Physics by Jennifer OuelletteDeath by Black Hole: And Other Cosmic Quandaries by Neil deGrasse TysonThe Elegant Universe: Superstrings, Hidden Dimensions, and the Quest for the Ultimate Theory by Brian Greene (and just about anything else by Green, Kaku, or Hawking that isn't published in a journal)

In this book, Brian Greene draws on recent developments in physics and mathematics to motivate arguments that entertain the possibility (some rather convincingly) that our universe, rather than being central in any cosmic order, may actually be just part of a multiverse supporting many other parallel universes. The book is not as easy to access as Greene's earlier book, The Fabric of the Cosmos, and appeals more to the intermediate/advanced reader who is well-grounded in fundamental concepts of string theory and cosmology. However, the work develops the arguments with great patience and very systematically, and the reader is left to reflect on the radical conclusions and implications, even if they are unable to fully digest the underlying scientific arguments.Greene's fundamental premise in this book is that multiple streams of scientific and mathematical thinking overwhelmingly suggest that our commonsense picture of reality as we know it is only part of a grander whole. This premise, Greene argues, is a natural progression of the same scientific ideas that initiated the Copernican revolution, and that our universe's non-centrality is merely an extension of similar earth-shattering ideas that historically challenged the centrality of the earth vis-a-vis the Sun and other planets. The author offers several proposals for the existence of parallel universes, devoting a chapter exclusively to each to develop the foundational arguments and support. Most of these are developed using mathematics and quantum physics, and ultimately paint a vision of a grand cosmos so big that a cosmic horizon restricts our understanding of what lies yonder since light cannot reach us from universes farther away.The proposals developed in this book are as follows: the Quilted Multiverse (infinite universes repeat across space based on manifesting conditions), the Inflationary Multiverse (where inflationary cosmology leads to the establishment of several bubble universes), Brane Multiverse (motivated by string theory's brane structure and higher dimensions which leads to co-existence of parallel universes) and the related Cyclic Multiverse (resulting from brane collisions that follow a cycle), Landscape Multiverse (where Quantum tunneling in a string landscape create bubbles of new space that co-exist), Quantum Multiverse (that results from Hugh Everett's challenge to the Copenhagen interpretation of Schrodinger's wave function equation, suggesting that probability waves simultaneously co-exist and present alternative realities), the Holographic Multiverse which proposes all perceived reality as a hologram (based on Hawking's work with black hole boundaries and Maldacena's surprising conclusions that connect physics at the boundary and bulk, equating quantum field physics with string theory with uncanny exactness), and finally, the Simulated and Ultimate Multiverses (which motivate technological and pure mathematical bases for the existence of parallel universes).This is a very thought-provoking read if the reader is willing to continue in spite of content challenges in the science. The bigger picture is always lucid and the general takeaways cannot be argued against, even though much depends on future endeavors experimentally testing many of the support pillars for these hypotheses. If nothing else, the reader is forced to ponder the contextual inconsequence not only of one's own existence in the grand cosmology but the very universe we presently inhabit, and for a moment suspend one's ego that usually overwhelms...

There's not much I can add in praise of Greene's scientific writing that I haven't put into reviewing "The Elegant Universe" and "The Fabric of the Cosmos." Greene is, hands down, the best science writer I've ever read, on so many levels it amazes me. Here he tackles the most mind-blowing aspect of cosmology: the fact that the mathematical unfolding of every cosmological theory today leads unfailingly to the idea that we are but one in a (usually) infinite collection of universes, collectively referred to as a "multiverse."Just as the search for an ultimate particle has led us down through the atom to the nucleus to the proton to the quark to (possibly) the string, so the search for ultimate "bigness" expanded from the Earth to the solar systems to the galaxy to the galactic cluster to the universe, now it has downgraded the entire universe to but a button in the sewing drawer of existence.Each branch of physics – quantum mechanics, string theory, cosmic inflation, holography, etc. – has posited (or more correctly been led mathematically) to a slightly or in some cases radically different view of what the multiverse would look like. It's silly to go into all of them in a review, especially since I couldn't touch either the detail or the elegance of Greene's presentation. But a couple theoretic setups struck me for one reason or another.The Quantum Multiverse assumes – again through mathematical necessity – every probabilistic outcome of a quantum event is actually realized and creates a separate branching universe. In other words, if I've got this right, the probabilities inherent in "quantum jitters" cause every single particle at every instant to generate a range of universes that each goes its own way. Seems like things would get crowded, no matter how you figure the separation of these universes. Despite the math involved, the conclusion seems silly. I'm 99.99999% sure it's hooey. Of course, that .00001 may be off somewhere creating a place I'd rather be, who knows?The Ultimate Universe, based on the idea that math IS reality, claims, rather simply but all-encompassingly, that we should consider any possible universe, based on any possible mathematical system, to be a reality. Thus you might have universes with an entirely different set of mathematic laws where reality unfolds in ways we can't even imagine. You even have to include the universe of Nothing – the total empty universe.I have two problems with this: First, can you really say mathematics = reality? Calculus leads to the computation of "instantaneous" speed and acceleration. But, in reality, there is no such thing: speed and acceleration are dependent on time, and in the instant, there is no time. Calculus is magnificently useful, but to say that it IS a form of reality? I can' swallow that. Second, the Nothing universe would have no math. Period. Seems to me to kind of blow that theory."The Hidden Reality" is the capstone of what, so far, has been Greene's trilogy. It's the most difficult of his three books, on some levels, but beyond engrossing. Reading it, I felt I too was in a different universe.

Amazon.com Review The Elegant Universe and The Fabric of the Cosmos here treats all viable alternate realities to a laudably fair shake. For a book exploring the most far-reaching implications of bleeding-edge mathematics, The Hidden Reality is surprisingly light on math, written as it is "for a broad audience ... its only prerequisite the will to persevere." Such perseverance pays off with a motley cast of potential universes featuring doppelgängers, strings, branes, quantum probabilities, holographs, and simulated worlds. The result is that rare accomplishment in science writing for a popular audience: a volume that explains the science and its consequences while stimulating the imagination of even the uninitiated. Oliver Sacks on The Hidden Reality Brian Greene is not only a profound cosmological thinker--a pioneer of string theory--but a writer of exceptional clarity and charm. His books--_The Hidden Reality_ takes us deeper still, and it has a special personal quality and warmth that is evident from the opening of the book, when Greene recollects how, as a boy, he was fascinated by the multiple reflections in parallel mirrors. He has never lost this childlike wonder at the world of physics, but he brings it now to examining theories of multiple universes, of the continual birth of universes, starting long before our own. . . and destined to continue, perhaps, to the end of time.In the 1930s, as a boy myself, I read   From Publishers Weekly Starred Review. "There was a time when ÿuniverse' meant ÿall there is,' " writes Greene, but soon we may have to redefine that word, along with our own meager understanding of the cosmos. A theoretical physicist and celebrated author, Greene offers intrepid readers another in-depth yet marvelously accessible look inside the perplexing world of modern theoretical physics and cosmology. Greene's book The Elegant Universe explained late 20th-century efforts to find a unified theory of everything, culminating with string theory. But string theory opened up a new can of worms, hinting at the possible existence of multiple universes and other strange entities. The possibility of other universes existing alongside our own like holes in "a gigantic block of Swiss cheese" seems more likely every day. Beginning with relativity theory, the Big Bang, and our expanding universe, Greene introduces first the mind-blowing multiplicity of forms those parallel universes might take, from patchwork quilts or stretchy "branes" to landscapes and holograms riddled with black holes. With his inspired analogies starring everyone from South Park's Eric Cartman to Ms. Pac-Man and a can of Pringles, Greene presents a lucid, intriguing, and triumphantly understandable state-of-the-art look at the universe. Let me begin by stating that I am a Brian Greene fan. I've read 'The Elegant Universe', 'The Fabric of the Cosmos', and even 'Icarus at the Edge of Time'. I thoroughly enjoyed each one. Of course, I also enjoyed the NOVA/PBS program, 'The Elegant Universe', based upon Greene's book by the same name and I'm looking forward to the upcoming program based upon his second book, 'The Fabric of the Cosmos'. Brian Greene has the ability to take a subject that is immensely complicated and translate it into language that the average person who has an interest in science can easily understand. I am, admittedly, a science enthusiast, but, by no means, am I an expert. Despite this, Greene's books kept me captivated from the first page to the last. The one exception was this book.I purchased Greene's book at my local Barnes & Noble store the very day it was released. I'm not sure why I did so, as I didn't begin reading it until several weeks later. However, I suppose my purchase of his book was a testament to my fandom and so it is with great pain that I give his latest work only two stars. Now, by all means, if you are more technically inclined to understand the subject of string theory and, in particular, so-called multiverse theory, then you may wish to disregard my comments. But, for the average reader, this was, as has been stated in other reviews, quite a difficult read. In fact, difficulties began as early as chapter two.The various multiverse theories are speculative, at best, as is readily admitted by Greene. In fact, Greene goes so far as to admit even that string theory, that for which he is so widely known, is largely speculative. However, 'The Hidden Reality' takes speculation to a new level and, while multiverse theories are arrived at by way of mathematical calculations and, hopefully, by some experimental verification in the future, the theories explained by Greene are such a wild departure from anything one might experience or imagine, that attempting to do so while reading this work made enjoyment of its contents all the more difficult.My criticism of Greene's latest book, however, is not with the science behind that with which he attempts to enlighten the reader, but with the delivery. As I read this book, I felt almost as if it had been published before its time. That is to say that Brian Greene introduces us to things that are so cutting-edge, that even the scientific community that has developed these theories cannot agree on their accuracy or whether their potential discoveries of worthy of scientific merit. With that said, it stretches the bounds of reasonableness to expect that the average reader (albeit, the reader with an interest in science) will find this book particularly engaging. To be fair, Greene admonishes the reader early on that this may be the case. And so it is with regret that I must agree.

A heady, intellectual adventure from start to finish, Brain Greene's The Hidden Reality boldly goes where only Star Trek and The Matrix have gone before: the topic of parallel universes. Tackling nine different theories of parallel realities, Mr. Greene carefully explains the science that supports them and in the process manages to prove that for all the goofy pseudo-science found in Star Trek (and I mean that affectionately), the underlying concept of an evil Spock is actually grounded in the deepest laws of the cosmos.Like John Gribben and Carl Sagan, Mr. Greene has the enviable ability to discuss complex ideas in an engaging way, favoring simple language and amusing anecdotes as a way of getting his ideas across. Whether he discusses quantum mechanics, string theory or black holes, Mr. Greene is able to carry us deftly from one idea to the next. Admittedly, this isn't the first book on cosmology or quantum theory that I've read, so I'm already well grounded in many of the book's basic concepts. It's possible that a quick survey of the Idiot's Guide to Cosmology may be in order - or just maybe just read Mr. Greene's other books, The Elegant Universe and The Fabric of the Cosmos. The ideas presented here would seem esoteric if they weren't the natural extension of physics most common theories. A Quilted Multiverse (parallel worlds spread out across infinite space), a Quantum Multiverse (everything the can happen does happen) and the Simulated Multiverse (ala The Matrix) are each presented as complete viable scientific conclusions. Mr. Greene clearly has his own favorite choices, but this doesn't keep him from discussing the controversy surrounding each theory - nor does he shy away from a discussion of why we should bother trying to unravel the mysteries of our reality at all.For all the science, however, at it's heart The Hidden Reality is a philisophical exploration of the most basic question of existence: why. Whichever theory is true, it seems likely (scientifically speaking) that we are part of one multiverse or another, an idea which has the potential to make our existence seem less unique then we like it to be. The Hidden Reality has the possibility to provoke reactions similar to those that followed Copernicus' revelation about the motion of planetary bodies: in other words, it can shake one's perception of both reality and our place in the world. I'd love to read a religious response to this book: not one that ignores the science, but rather one that finds a way to incorporate it into a religious theory.Although, it's possible this already exists. After all, the theologian Bishop Berkeley theorized that we only exist in the mind of God, which seems to be nothing but an extension of Mr. Greene's idea of a simulated reality.

The Hidden Reality contains a lot of theoretical information regarding multiple universes, holographic universes, string theory, quantum multiple universes and computer generated universes. These are incredibly strange and mind blowing concepts to be sure, but the thing I found most strange and mind blowing about Brian Greene’s The Hidden Reality was the complete absence of the phrase “I don’t know”. Instead, Greene walks us through a physicists land of make believe for which not a shred of evidence exists. I understand that there are thousands of physicists out there who need to publish papers to advance their careers. I also realize that theoretical physics has largely stagnated since the exciting advances in quantum theory that began in the 1920’s leaving few topics to write about. But surely the efforts of these intelligent individuals is better spent on a more productive endeavor than the navel gazing that string theory has become. One would think that after almost 40 years of work that string theory and multi-verse proponents would be required to put up a single unambiguous piece of evidence in support of their claims. But they can’t, and some say that they never will. The following quote sums it up pretty well:"For more than a generation, physicists have been chasing a will-o’-the-wisp called string theory. The beginning of this chase marked the end of what had been three-quarters of a century of progress. Dozens of string-theory conferences have been held, hundreds of new Ph.D.s have been minted, and thousands of papers have been written. Yet, for all this activity, not a single new testable prediction has been made, not a single theoretical puzzle has been solved. In fact, there is no theory so far—just a set of hunches and calculations suggesting that a theory might exist. And, even if it does, this theory will come in such a bewildering number of versions that it will be of no practical use: a Theory of Nothing."—Jim HoltI suppose I found Greene’s uncritical presentation too close to the fairy tales one would expect from Dr. Seuss or Billy Graham. It would be far more honest of him to simply admit the truth and say ... I don’t know, nobody does. Update: I should have finished the book before writing the review. He actually says almost the exact words above ... IN THE NEXT TO LAST SENTENCE IN THE BOOK!! His readers would have been better served if he put it on the cover.

I've read Brian Greene's previous two books (Elegant Universe and Fabric of the Cosmos) and found this to follow a similar pattern. The first couple of chapters devoted to the historical pedigree of cosmology (so Newton, Einstein etc.) the next few chapters devoted to developments in hard science, and the last few chapters devoted to cutting-edge or speculative science. There's obviously some repetition over the three books (especially in the earlier chapters) but there's enough novelty to justify reading them all. So how does this book fare compared to the previous ones?To begin with, maybe I've just become much smarter over the last couple of years, but I found the material this work to be much easier to grasp than the material in his earlier books. Although his explanations border on patronising at times (such as using Eric Cartman rolling down a hill to explain inflaton fields) he does have a knack of simplifying very complex concepts into comprehensible analogies, and to that end this is probably his most accessible book yet. He was also more forthright about the scientific difficulties which face string theory at the moment (primary among them, the lack of supporting evidence), which I think makes a nice change from the untrammelled optimism of his earlier books.The faults? I think the science quickly veers from grounded discussions about the possibilities of multiverses (the scientific pursuit of which forms the unifying theme of this book) to rather less-grounded discussions about holographic universes and the possibility of our living inside of a computer simulation, by which stage my eyes began to glaze over. The discussions were fun in their way (and - as I said - Greene is generally explicit about noting where he is deviating from established science into wanton speculation), but given that the "multiverse" topic is already an inherently speculative idea, I would have preferred more material about the hard, scientific case for the multiverse (which - I must stress - Greene does a good job of presenting here) rather than these rather sci-fi flights of fancy. But, overall, it's a minor quibble. If you enjoyed his previous works (which I'd recommend starting with if you haven't), you'll probably enjoy this one too. 3.5 stars.

The Hidden Reality is an intriguing journey to the frontiers of physics, explaining how different, sometimes unrelated, theories are independently converging on the probability that there is, and in fact must be, more than one universe. The long story short is that, as we learn more and more about the nature of reality, in order for physicists to make sense of some of the more baffling facets of our universe, it has become increasingly necessary to invoke various types of alternative universes to fully explain the data. The math--if not the evidence (yet)--is pointing toward the likelihood of an infinite number of parallel universes, taking an infinite number of forms. An infinite number of yous and mes living different lives throughout the unimaginably vast expanse of the "multiverse."And, once again, humankind is demoted from the centrality of our place in the cosmos. Our species, our planet, our solar system, our galaxy, and now, not even our entire universe, are nowhere near the "center" of anything. There is no center to speak of, really. The cosmos is a mysterious and wondrous place, isn't it?Greene is an excellent tour guide to each of the possible parallel universes, and is a gifted writer to boot--capable of generating a seemingly endless reserve of analogies and examples grounded in common experience that are employed to illuminate ideas that are anything but. It's a skill that particularly useful in outlining the current state of understanding in the field of quantum mechanics--it never ceases to amaze me just how fundamentally weird the tiny constituent parts of the universe are. Greene is also quite good at explaining the Anthropic Principle, a shockingly useful concept that provides a powerful rationale as to why our universe (and planet) seem just right for life. (Essentially: If it weren't, then we wouldn't be here to wonder at it. There's more to it than that, of course.)I'd recommend this book to anyone. Some of the sections offer more challenging material, for all but the most intrepid explorer, but Greene does an effective job of telling the more cursory reader what portions safely can be skipped. So, just sit right back and let Greene be your tour guide for cosmic adventure...

Brian Greene writes books on cosmology and string theory that are remarkably approachable. He writes in a clear and entertaining way that makes you almost believe you understand string theory and quantum physics. This book walks you through theories of multiple universes. Sci-fi fans have always assumed that parallel universes were possible, but Greene walks us through how physicists came to believe these were theoretically possible. Along the way, he talks about questions like the meaning of probability in an infinite universe. Twice as likely implies that one possibility occurs an infinite number of times and the other occurs, um, two times infinity number of times ("this sounds like the tortured math of one-upping seven-year-olds"). Speaking of probabilities, he describes the work of philosopher Nick Bostrom, who reasoned that simulated universes like the Matrix (if possible) would be presumably much easier to create than real ones. As a result, statistically speaking the chances that we live in a simulated universe are much higher than that we are living in a "real" one. Hmm. And my favorite topic is the idea that the universe as we know it is an illusion--a holographic projection of matter that exists on a distant outer periphery. The scary part is that there is math behind this theory--something to do with the fact that information embodied on the outer shell of a boundary described in terms of quantum theory is identical to information inside the shell described in terms of string theory. (I didn't really get it either, but it sounds logical ;^) ) Anyhow, the point is that by focusing on parallel universes, this book describes some cutting edge cosmological theory. If you've read other books on cosmology, then this is a great book to push you out of your comfort zone once things like Schrodinger's cat and entanglement theory no longer seem bizarre to you. On the other hand, if you're new to the topic, I'd start with something like Greene's Fabric of the Universe or Stephen Hawking's A Brief History of Time or Kip Thorne's and Stephen Hawking's Black Holes and Time Warps. Greene also has a TED talk and discussed the topic on Nova.

While this 2011 work just barely predates the 4 July 2012 discovery of a new particle that physicists suspected was the Higgs boson, I feel this is the best book I have read of several laying on the brane-based multi-verse theories. I feel as a popularizer of notions and having a low bar of entry, it is even better than Warped Passages: Unraveling the Mysteries of the Universe's Hidden Dimensions. This is very easy to follow with clear analogies such as blurry photographs of a fly and the Heisenberg's uncertainty principle and similarly works well to explain simply ideas like Planck constant and information capacity, the Copenhagen interpretation and, new to me, the inflaton field theorized to drive cosmic inflation in the very early universe. In short, an excellent summary introduction by a researched in cosmology with a gift for explanation.

This guy is without a doubt one of the best science writers going around. His style is clear, engaging, and informative without being condescending, and he has an uncanny knack of making you feel like you've understood what he's talking about even when you probably haven't. The Hidden Reality is tougher going than The Fabric of the Cosmos (2004), his previous bestseller, but this is unsurprising given the fact that it tackles a topic that is less general and inherently more challenging, even in terms of the basic overall concept. Greene uses the principles of inflationary cosmology, quantum mechanics, string theory and a host of other theoretical frameworks to introduce no less than nine possible models of a reality in which our universe is not, in fact, the universe at all, but merely one of a (potentially infinite) number of alternative universes containing both micro- and macrosopically different physical features. The Hidden Reality really is a slog at times, but Greene's infectious enthusiasm for his subject and his ability to translate difficult concepts into comparatively lucid everyman terms make it an enjoyable slog nonetheless. As someone who lives and breathes the humanities, I think the thing I really like about Greene is that he has no polemical agenda, no interest in trumpeting the superiority of science over all other disciplines or reducing existence to a dry agglomeration of quantifiable data with no scope for all the complexities and mysteries and beauties of life. He infuses all of his books with the same sense of awe I always feel when looking at the stars and writes with a wide-eyed wonder, as if he's encouraging us to constantly pinch ourselves as a reminder that we really are here in this vast, infinitely astonishing universe, or possibly "multiverse" (though if one of the models Greene outlines is correct, we might not actually be here at all). Greene is a brilliant, eloquent advocate of the value of searching for knowledge and understanding, even when that search takes us beyond what's familiar or seemingly reasonable. I'm sure his next book, whenever it comes, will be another reality-shaking read.

Unbelievable parallel, cyclic, quilted, holographic, simulated and many other scenarios that the string theory and the quantum physics allows to arrive at the same mind bending conclusion. We are such an insignificant being, in such an insignificant corner of such an insignificant universe, in such a vast and incomprehensible 'multi-verse'... The good news is, if you found your head spinning and feel like you are somehow lost in some unfathomable dimension of reality or mathematical complexity, you are not alone. Even the author seems to be lost, his mind and his grasp on the reality I would say... While the author admits speculative nature of many of these theories (better to say hypothetical realms with some mathematical explanations), he does a good job in listing several arguments that point to the same conclusion, that our universe is only one of the many. He doesn't claim any scientific rigor to this conclusion (which is sad. see Scientific American August 2011 issue challenging the idea of Multiverses in scientific grounds), but I guess the point that emerges out of reading this book is that when several different, unrelated, and sometimes disjoint paradigms suggest the same thing, although none can be independently and empirically tested or proven, one is inclined to think that it is more than just a mathematical happenstance.I am fond of reading sci-fi books as well as scientific books and couldn't really tell the difference in many of the passages of this book. Speculations backed by untested and untestable theoretical explanations, with fantastically amazing implications on how our entire species should identify itself and rationalize its adventures to the outer-verses made reading this book more interesting for me. I am happy that I read it back to back with The Elegant Universe, which made understanding many of the theoretical groundings of this book much easier for someone unfamiliar with the mathematical complexities of the String theory...

The Hidden Reality is a brilliantly written book that does not impart as much proven knowledge as Fabric of Cosmos or The Elegant Universe but takes the readers to the highly speculative, part-philosophical ride on the nature of reality. In the nine different multiverse theories discussed here, the underlying theme - as discussed towards the end - is that the only thing that does not make sense is why our universe can not be unique and special, the way our galaxy, sun or earth are not. The theories are often complex and always speculative, but lucidly explained. While one may not understand all the finer points, the author has a great ability to return to the main messages which are always crystal clear.That said, the theories discussed here often appear like new, scientific religions. The infinite regress problem that used to trouble anyone logically analysing religion (if God created us, who created God etc) are now afflicting the universe and whatever latest elementary particles/fields. As per science, their has to be something behind their finely balanced structure - like practically infinite number of universes of which we just happen to be one. Lest this is ever proven, chances are that someone will then need to come out with multi-multiverse theories to justify why our multiverse can not be unique. At some point, science has to grapple the issue of the beginning or a singularity or uniqueness of our reality. There is one whole which may not be a single universe, as it is not a single star or atom, but still it must exist. Science and philosophy are not complete until we reach there.
