If multiverse theories' main foundation (in the absence of provable assertions) is that our universe can not be unique, it is on a massively wrong footing. And this is where this book has its shortcomings, in the eventual conclusion. That said, a must read for anyone who likes to get to the deeper issues of existence or learn more about the latest scientific theories.

At one point in this book Brian Greene poses the question of whether as human beings, we are equipped with the mental capacity to understand our universe. For this to happen our universe must have produced something that is able to understand itself, and if our universe is really part of many, it must have produced something greater than itself. In other words, we might be woefully unfit to understand the mechanisms of our universe. That in and of itself is thought provoking enough.On that note, I'd like to ask the question, are books fit to explain the grand ideas that Greene tries to discuss here? In other words, are 2-dimensional words and pictures an adequate way to explain something like string theory? I found myself asking this question as soon as I got to that chapter (the previous chapters on quilted and expanding universes being "simple" enough for me to grasp somewhat), and after putting the book down in frustration and watching a PBS documentary called the Elegant Universe (which explained all these concepts perfectly well in a fraction of the time it took to read some of these chapters) I have to conclude that this book is almost a lost cause. As if Hidden Reality didn't already have so much going against it, it also becomes obvious that some of these theories are basically -- well just theories, almost philosophical in nature, and set up in way that they're essentially scientifically untestable at this point. In other words, we can't observe them in a lab. But, Greene says, if these theories are largely based on math, and it's truly only though math we can understand the universe, doesn't that make all of these theories valid? He seems to think so, while at the same time understanding people's hesitation.In the meantime, we're left with these theories,each more elaborate than the next, which mostly sound like desperate and creative attempts to dance around an actual answer.The ideas in this book are grand, but the lack of substance unfortunately leave the reader unsatisfied.

I had heard about some of the parallel universe ideas before, but not about all of them. Brian Greene has managed to piece together all the possible parallel universe concepts and compiled into one single book in an accessible manner. This helps an enthusiastic reader to compare and understand the various multiverse ideas in a coherent manner. Although Brian Greene is a string theorist, he doesn't give undue prominence to the multiverse ideas originated from the string theory. Out of them quilted, quantum, holographic, simulated and ultimate multiverse ideas were easy to grasp. The descriptions of the others were not that easy. Especially I didn't understand the difference between landscape, inflationary and cyclic multiverses. Maybe the idea about the inflationary big bang puts me off as it always sounds like a tweak in whatever manner it is described. The inflation field and swizz cheese with multiple holes forming different universes was only understood as, well, swizz cheese with multiple holes.I loved the detailed treatment of the quantum multiverse. I have heard about this before and had a rough idea about it. But Greene had managed to bring out all the subtleties originating from this. Especially the place of the probabilistic description of the classical quantum mechanical interpretation in this interpretation. I think the difficulty in managing the idea of probability in many worlds approach is not only a problem about the quantum mechanics, but in general about the general probability theory. I would be interested to read further treatment on this.Brian Greene has struggled all the way to avoid mathematical equations in this book too. Maybe he believes in the infamous quote about each equation reducing the sale of a book by thousand. I would have preferred a feeling of struggle to understand a Hamiltonian's evolution in a theoretical physics rather than the pretentious feeling of satisfaction after reading about a 'wiggling string' in two dimensions and myriads of metaphors. But, then I shouldn't read Brian Greene in the first place.

I am probably doing this book a disservice by reviewing it. The problem is, I listened to the audiobook version of The Hidden Reality. It's not that the author, Brian Greene, who reads the book himself, is a bad narrator. Quite the contrary, I think the guy could do this for a living if he wasn't a theoretical physicist. It's just that it is easy for a mind to wander momentarily when listening and then you miss things. Normally not a problem, but when you're listening to an explanation of string theory or general relativity or the brain-slice multiverse theory, then you may quickly miss the point and have difficulty following the subsequent explanations. And unlike with a book, you cannot just quickly rescan what you've missed, you have to rewind.Anyway, The Hidden Reality is all about how our universe may be just one of the perhaps infinitely many universes in a multiverse. Various possible multiverse theories are explored. There is the inflationary theory, the bubble one, the holographic one, my favorite the simulated multiverse theory and even the ultimate one. The science supporting each such theory is explained, whether be it Newtonian physics, Einstein's relativity, quantum fields or, of course and possibly most prominently, string theory. Quite often Greene resorts to colorful metaphors, such as using Cartman from South Park rolling down the mountain to explain inflationary cosmology, but I wonder if that actually does more harm than good, since it obscures and possibly trivializes the subject. I mean, I didn't quite get it - not that it means anything.Fascinating subjects are broached here, but as I said, one might get more out of it by reading rather than listening to this book, which I once already abandoned listening to due to the problems described above. I am going to try to atone by actually reading one of Greene's previous books on the subject of string theory.

I borrowed “The Hidden Reality” as an e-book from the library, twice, each for 21 days, and on the 21st day of my second loan, I bought it through Amazon because I was only halfway finished, and I wanted to have it as a reference. You know, because if you are not a physicist and not even inclined to understand complex (or, OK, some basic) science and math, and if you do not hang out with scientists and science/math nerds and people who talk regularly about inflationary cosmology and quarks and quantum tunneling, then you obviously will find yourself needing to refer to this book at least weekly.And yet the book managed to a) squeeze some actual learning into my not-very-sciencey (or mathy) brain, and b) inspire me to consider reading other books about physics. From a non-science-brain perspective, “The Hidden Reality” is a mixture of helpful allegorical explanations and hard-to-follow science. Though I understood a lot of it only in the moment (like, I’d forget what something was a couple paragraphs later), I am surprised to find that I actually remember some things and can even explain them, though obviously in less sophisticated and eloquent terms. It isn’t an easy book to read, if you’re an extreme amateur like me, but then I am not sure what to compare it with since it’s the first real look at physics I’ve ever read.A few of my favorite topics/vocabulary:*entropy and the Second Law of Thermodynamics*redshifting*quantum tunneling*cosmic horizon*event horizon (it’s not just a creepy movie!)*parallax (it’s fun to have a word to describe how objects appear to move depending on which eye you open)And on a final note, did you know that there are real scientists in the world who believe that parallel universes might actually exist? Yeah, crazy times, I know.

Beyond the farthest star we've seen, is there another expanse of matter we cannot, and will never see? Have other big bangs formed similar expanses separate to ours? And how do we really know that what we are seeing is real and not a simulation in some sophisticated computer? This last one is particularly thought provoking. Perhaps the history of science is merely an accumulation of ideas which we are deceived into thinking have consistency and meaning. Not such a new idea in light of The Matrix, but challenging when read as a serious idea rather than watched for entertainment.The premise for this book is that the math's and physics that has so richly informed our picture of the natural world also suggests that many 'other' universes exist. In some cases this is relatively well founded, whilst in others it is more tenuous. String theory, for all the popularity it has had, has not been easy to 'prove' for phenomena in this universe, so extrapolation to others is a stretch. Not that Greene is trying to suggest otherwise. All along he points out that these ideas are virtually impossible to verify, and may never be, but offers suggestions that could do so if the technology were available/possible. This was surprisingly readable. Considering that the ideas draw on some of the most advanced physics around - relativity, quantum mechanics, string, etc. - most of the content is descriptive and makes good use of analogy, illustrations, etc. to help get the pint across. I read most of the 'extra' material in each chapter and didn't find it hard going, although the notes only got a half look. Not that the content doesn't require some mind-stretching. Amidst the chapters is a very good description of the anthropic principle, and other notes (such as how big the universe is) which were not perhaps new, but freshly told. Liked it.

half way through. started great, a sudden turn to string theory (again!) and very strange and dated analogies have pushed me to another book but I will finish this. did I mention brian greene pushes string theory? oh and he talks about string theory. maybe brian greene can finish a book (just one book) without pushing an untestable theory.1/29/18Good explanation of the black hole information paradox and the holographic principle, but the chapter ends with ANOTHER push for string theory.

There's quite a few head-scratchers here, but alas, that is physics. After having read "The Elegant Universe" and "Fabric of the Cosmos," I was pretty pumped to pick this up. I liked the start; felt that it was solid, recapping some of his previous work and getting the reader boned up on the knowledge that they will need to push through the entirety of the book. And then he just started going down rabbit hole after rabbit hole. This book (and all other Greene books) was supposed to be for the lay reader and those who have a neophyte's understanding of theoretical physics. So why all the jumping around? He's just starting on what new advancement's have been made on Brane/M Theory and then he's rushing off to the Planck length and black holes and the mathematics and conceptualizing of the Quilted Universe and then there's the Swiss Cheese Universe concept and oh-my-goodness-I'm-listening-to-this-on-audiobook-and-can't-hardly-even-stop-the-disc. On one hand, it's very much my fault for choosing the medium that I did to experience this work (i.e., audio). On the other, subject matter vacillated so quickly that who could keep up with it? Where both of his other books were concrete, this one alluded me on so many levels as to relegate it to forgettable status.I agree with other reviewers. To a physicist, this is surely so simple as to be almost a waste of their time. To the lay reader, it's quite difficult, giving you nothing more than a mental concept...a hard to grasp one at that...with the details being, what I would call, riff-raff. Kind of sad that I spent the time listening to it. Should have read it instead. All I remember is the first 4 or 5 discs and the last one, and that's simply not good enough.

I'm a big Brian Greene fan and eagerly anticipated reading this book. While most of my high expectations were met, there were a few unavoidable downsides as well. First of all, I appreciated how this book challenged my notions about the universe we live in and how it plays out in the largest sense of the cosmos. There are many interesting theories, each one superbly explained with Greene's keen ability to distill highly complex ideas down to the essential and widely accessible core principles. Even though the ideas are understandable by those with only moderate scientific inclination, I never feel like Greene is talking down to us or dumbing things down too far. The many theories make for an interesting read on possible configurations for the universe(s), but at the same time also offer the greatest weakness as well.It's fun to imagine space as explained by Greene. I was disappointed -not by Greene or his writing- but by the lack of conclusiveness that these theories bring. While they each offer intriguing and applicable mathematical possibilities, the fact that some, almost all, or even none of them may be correct led me to feel that everything I had just learned might be nothing more than fantasy. At some point in the future, we may be able to determine which one, if any theory, is correct. But for now my curiosity remains insatiated by this gaping hole. It's not the author's fault, but merely a product of the material being covered.I almost gave this a five star review, but the lack of answers left me feeling that the book was unable to fulfill what I had been looking for. Curse my curiosity! If I could, I would have given it 4 1/2 stars, as it fell just short of giving me what I had hoped for.

This is Science light. Which means by staying away from the math and the deeper technicalese Greene gave us a book penetrable by the average reader. It is a tour of the many branches of modern physics which independently, or together, lead to the possiblity that this universe is not unique. Some suggest that it may not even be all that special. The great center piece is, of course, M-theory, the grand union of string and particle theory that practically mandates there be multiple universes. Greene reminds us that this is only part of the story though when he takes us on a tour of recognized but dismissed for decades multiple-universe implications of relativity and quantum physics that are now being rethought.Pros: Clear desriptions supported by good, clever real-world analogies to help you through the counterintuitive stuff. A bit of playful humor, and an eye toward storytelling. Diagrams that are actually useful. (A rarity in science books for the layman.) Discussion of just how testable some of these theories are (sone highly), with the recognition that to the extent that some cannot currently be tested they amountto mere speculation.Cons: Padding. In chapter 10 Greene considers possibilities drawn less from science than philosphy, making them dubious content in a book about science. Stuff not born of the implications or mathematics of a theory based on observation, but of the pure imagination. Barely justifiable I suppose in that they include the kinds of speculation some readers already have.But the cons are a small thing in an otherwise highly informative and readily digestible book. It's an excellent layman's guide to modeern multiple universe theories.

Finished The Hidden Reality [audiobook] the other day, but have to say it wasn't my favorite of reads. The book is all about different theories of the 'multiverse' and/or the existence of infinitely parallel universes. I've heard of the idea before, and while I think it's fun to play with mentally, I do feel like it seems like a distraction from more testable physics. I do like that Greene does try to present the controversies, though personally, I felt like his defense was a bit weak. It's hard too, because I certainly appreciate that Greene is trying to boil down huge current theories in physics into something that a layman could read...but the problem with that is always that I come away feeling like I don't have enough expertise to really test the merits of his argument, despite his explanations. I love making things accessible, but I wonder sometimes if it's dangerous to make things accessible if the average person remains unequipped to really judge your points adequately. A tension that exists in many areas of life, I haven't yet figured out what the best way to balance things are.I will say that I do appreciate his analogies, he has a knack for teaching things, though to be sure he oversimplifies them at times. He does seem honest about the limitations of things though, and I appreciate that he does attempt to sketch out where controversy exists, etc. He didn't have to do that, and the fact that he did adds some credibility. I also feel like this was a book I should've read in hard copy, because when you get distracted in an audiobook, it's hard to 'go back a page'...and I definitely know I missed a few things sometimes for that reason, which is difficult in a book on a topic as complex as this.smile emoticon
Greene does it once again. While this book is a little deeper than his previous on the same subjects, it is still easily digestible and I recommend it.

For a mathematician and theoretical physicist, Greene is particularly adept at explaining not only the essentials of relativity and string theory but also more general ideas (such as the assertion that science's "core mandate" is to find regularities on the workings of the universe) to mass consumption audiences. Although some more well-read readers may complain that he spends too much time rehashing high school physics (like Newton's laws), average readers will probably find Greene's writing a good mix of facts they should remember from school and completely new theoretical physics concepts (new at least to the book's intended non-string-theorist audience).I've read parts of Greene's other books, and I always really want to enjoy them (because he's an engaging writer), but find that it's hard to get past his unwavering commitment to string theory -- which he admits is still, after decades of research, still just a mathematical exercise (numbers on a page). His latest book attempts to present other possibilities of multiverse scenarios besides just those based on sting theory, and the breadth of possibilities he lays out and explains makes for an interesting read. This is not an academic text filled with math. However, it can be dense and even boring at times (chapter seven, for example, can probably be skipped)... If you have even a passing interest in multiple universes, you'll probably get something out of this book, but it takes some persistence to get through it cover to cover. Pick out the interesting bits -- Greene usually provides sufficient recaps to allow readers to skip from chapter to chapter without too much confusion.

This book is filled with trippy, speculative science and is quite fun. I remember when I was 7, I was at the observatory with my dad, and while looking at an orrery I wondered, naturally, if that is kind of what the solar system looks like. It probably looks something like that, I thought, and it sits in the milky way, which I can see a picture that describes what it looks like, and the milky way sits in the local group and I can picture a group of galaxies that includes the milky way and the Andromeda galaxy, and that sits in the universe, what does the whole universe look like? My dad was kind of a prankster, and so, not actually knowing the answer (this was in like 1969, so really it was not well known at that point, though I recall several years later being able to find some astronomy books that contained the dots on the balloon demo of the expanding universe), he told me that Einstein says that the universe looks like a key. It took me a couple years to figure out that there is no way that could be true.Anyway, if one wants to read something about the bleeding edge research as to what everything looks like, this is a good, non-technical book that presents many fun, mind expanding, scientific theories for one's consideration and amusement. Included: the quilted multiverse (universes beyond our cosmic horizon) the inflationary multiverse (little bubbles of collapsed regions of the hypothetical inflation field), the quantum multiverse (the cat lives in the universe next door), brane theory, the cyclic multiverse, and the ultimate,ate ensemble of all universes with a mathematics. No mention of Amber, The Courts of Chaos, or Tanelorn, however.

This was not the easiest of the Brian Greene books to read, but then it was a grand tour of the bleeding edge of physics, all told without Math. You have to expect that there would be some stop, go back, read that again moments in there, and there were. There were fewer references to pop culture icons this time around, and if felt like those ommisions must have been because someone complained about Simpsons references not belonging in a serious book or something. There were missed to some degree, and if felt like he was working a lot harder to explain things without them.The base subject of the book itself is mind altering: Like licking the cover and finding it laced with LSD. For weeks and weeks ager I have returned to think about what I read, and consider it more closely. I went on a total mind candy bender while I processed all the possibilities of the Multiverse.Mr. Greene is quite clear about the theoretical nature of all of it, but at the end we have 9 different, not mutually exclusive multiverses! If one were a betting person, it seems likely that even if all 9 are not correct, than at least some of them are, at least in some significant part, and in a way that is comforting. Knowing that, at the end of this 4+ dimensional universe, we are only at the beginning. There is way way way more.In my next incarnation, or in the next universe over, I hope I am a math wiz and can understand all the things that went into making this book that I do not know or understand without the math here/now.

In the start, the book seems like yet another physics minus mathematics book, trend of which have really picked up since the success of A Brief of Time. It does belong to that genre, but as it progresses, we find the book taking deeper look than others, explaining different types of multiverses theorized by current research in physics. The most interesting discussion I found, is the fact that as cutting edge physics research is breaking final frontiers of knowledge, it is entering a realm where its theoretical predictions are impossible to put to experiment. As multiverse by definition means, other universes, which are impossible to interact with, any theory predicting them cannot really be put to test(though there may be indirect hints making our belief in particular theory stronger or weaker). Yet, as the book details chapter by chapter, almost all versions of string theory and some interpretations of quantum theory give a strong hint of other universes out there.The most fascinating of all facts is how Second Law of Thermodynamics seems to be obeyed even inside Black Holes and how this fact provides a strong hint of parallel universe.From philosophical standpoint, it seems Brian Greene believes in broader role of physics, that is to 'really' explain all phenomenon. This seems to be different (in my limited understanding), from Bohr's position of not speaking much about what reality is, just speaking about what we observe reality to be(and probably no objective reality even exists). A fascinating read.

Though I am finding myself struggling to write a coherent review of this book, I can at least take comfort in the fact that there is another person, named Brad, in another parallel universe who has an account on Goodreads, who just read this book but perhaps, unlike me, can faithfully recapitulate what he just read. I cannot. I am trying hard enough not to smash my head on the counter.This was heavy. And I am a huge fan of Brian Greene. He has the rare ability to take complex theoretical physics and make them easily accessible and digestible. But, despite his best attempts this time around, my head still could not escape a thorough physics-induce butt kicking. Delving into the highly, highly, highly speculative subject of multiple universes – a subject, it turns out, that requires the most abstract concepts of physics and math in order to understand – Greene is at least forgiving enough to relegate the math to the notes section and offers the reader the opportunity to just skip ahead lest that reader throw himself into the fire. Didn’t really lighten the load for we readers in this universe all that much. The idea that is space is infinite, then patterns are necessarily destined to repeat made the most sense to me; it required nothing more than a grasp of infinity. After that, all bets are off. A decent enough head trip, to be sure, but not recommended laid back summer reading.

In Brian Greene’s latest tome, he once again tries to make string theory and all of it’s quirkiness (or quarkiness, and yes that is an awful pun) accessible to the common reader (actually, the common reader is probably too busy trying to find out if they can use the last Harry Potter book as a high chair, so perhaps the “common interested in physics and the universe” reader is more appropriate). The book is basically a theoretical physicists wet dream with its talk of the Many Worlds Multiverse, the Bubble Universe and it’s infinite possibilities, and everything else imaginable that needs to exist to make the math of string theory work (and Greene assures us that in this universe the math of string theory holds true as long as we simplify enough and remember to carry the ones).Anyway, this is a reasonably well written book with interesting concepts that show how theoretically we are not just all vibrating strings, but rather vibrating strings in 11 dimensions of infinite shapes across infinite worlds. So as you are reading this, there is another you (or infinite yous) in another universe (or infinite universes) actually writing this review yourself and I am the one reading it. I find the whole thing a bit preposterous, even if the math works (for now), but since this review won a Pulitzer in at least one of the infinite worlds of the multiverse, I guess I will accept string theory and the Many Worlds hypothesis for the time being.

I sure hope that I, in an alternate universe, understood this book thoroughly. Unfortunately, in this universe, I read this book and had moments of clarity and near-infinite understanding which were quickly dashed and replaced with confusion and vacant looks. Holographic multiverses and uncertainty waves in quantum measurements makes my brain hurt. Greene does provide a good survey of the many theories expounded by string theory and others into the possible nature of parallel universes. I think the most compelling possibilities were: 1) the quilted universe - if the universe is nearly infinite with finite components, then a finite number of patterns exist. Having a solar system and an earth and evolved life could just as easily crop up somewhere else) 2) brane multiverse - our universe exists in 3-dimensional brane which floats among other higher-dimensional branes (other parallel universes). Unfortunately our brian only processes data in 3 space so we are unable to access the other universes. (In string/M-theory's braneworld scenario) Simply put, multiple universes could exist but Greene is skeptical. And since, in the end, none of this makes any difference to my life, I too am skeptical. (but three cheers to the string theory scientists who continue to toil away at this philosophy)I would put this back on my list of books to re-read one day, unfortunately I don't think I will gain any more insight than what I already have.

Amazon.com Best Books of the Month Review: Take any of physics' major theories of the fundamental nature of the universe, extrapolate its math to the logical extreme, and you get some version of a (so far unobservable) parallel universe. And who better to navigate these hypothetical versions of the "multiverse" than Brian Greene? Normally an unflinching apologist for string theory, the bestselling author of 
The Elegant Universe
 and 
The Fabric of the Cosmos
 here treats all viable alternate realities to a laudably fair shake. For a book exploring the most far-reaching implications of bleeding-edge mathematics, The Hidden Reality is surprisingly light on math, written as it is "for a broad audience … its only prerequisite the will to persevere." Such perseverance pays off with a motley cast of potential universes featuring doppelgängers, strings, branes, quantum probabilities, holographs, and simulated worlds. The result is that rare accomplishment in science writing for a popular audience: a volume that explains the science and its consequences while stimulating the imagination of even the uninitiated. --Jason Kirk

There is a reason this book is called The Hidden Reality. I read this entire book, I was interested all the way through and if you asked me now what the hell he was talking about I would say, “I have no idea.” Whatever he was trying to say will remain forever past my grasp. I understand some of the science but my mind is too limited to truly grasp grand ideas.Greene spends a lot of time talking about the size and potential shapes of the universe (or even the possibility of multiple universes). Indeed if the universe is infinite (also there is some jabbering about finite matter in infinite space and it implications – at this point I would grab a glass of wine and watch Sponge Bob) mathematically it is also absolutely certain that there are an infinite number of copies of all of us. This means some meathead that who has my identical DNA is writing this same review somewhere. And apart from the compensating factor of his astonishingly good looks, he also is too inferior to comprehend this book.Though my brain is in the cognitive equivalent of a “swirly” right now, I still recommend this book for a couple of reasons. One, perhaps you likely have more functioning neurons that I do and understand this stuff. And Two, now I can blather on about string theory and the quantum calculating power that exist on the edge of black holes…while having no idea what I am talking about.

Quite simply, this book blew my mind. I was utterly unprepared for the slew of multiverse theories Brian Greene would inevitably put forward, detailing the big picture physics of holographic, Matrix-like, quantum, and virtual realities, among others. I'm not being dramatic when I say that there were times when the ideas presented by Greene were so mind bending I thought it unwise to read before bed! Some of my favorite passages of this nature occurred within the last two chapters or so.Brian Greene's first book, the Elegant Universe, was the book that began my love affair with physics. Greene has a unique knack for taking some of the most complex ideas conceived in all of human history, and making them understandable for just about anyone willing to think. And while Greene is clearly an ardent proponent of string theory, he very carefully lays out both the positive and negative aspects of each theory, and how they might be supported experimentally.For the more advanced physics readers, Greene includes endnotes with equations for quantum mechanics, relativity, etc. It is up to the reader how far to delve into each topic. This is the type of book you'll want to read slowly, as to digest each passage. From a physics perspective, it is more complex and "heavier" than both the Elegant Universe and Fabric of the Cosmos. I cannot stress enough the importance of setting a slow, deliberate pace. Following this strategy to the end, I was astounded by the result.

Standing on the edge of the latest discoveries on string theory, quantum physics and cosmology, this books probes into an area that used to be mere speculation: parallel universes.The result? Reality could be much stranger than any fiction in this world... and this universe. Fuelled by a series of Nova episodes (The elegant Universe, The Fabric of Cosmos), and a couple of books, 2012 re-sparked my always lingering interest in physics. This one answers (well, kind of) some of of most basic haunting questions: such as is the universe finite or infinite? what is the shape of it? I struggle wit the idea of limitless and yet finite on 3 dimensions (I'm ok with it on 2 and the ballon surface analogy).I think I finally get the multiverse theory based on the inevitable repetition based on a finite (however large) arrangement of elements, if those rearrangements are infinite. And even just glancing at the implications you have to wonder:Is living a multiverse the most significant or the most irrelevant discovery ever? I pondered this with Leon Marchebout on a terrace in Providencia, Guadalajara, and I concur that the answer is: both. Objectively, it can't have any effect in my life, or the life of my great, great, great grandchildren, or anyone I'll ever know. But we're subjective beings, and it does make a difference.I, subjectively declare, that physicist's inference of Multiverse, is the most life altering concepts ever, and it just occurred in our lifetime.

While it's possible that, given its terrestrial evolution, the human brain is only just able to comprehend the concepts laid out in The Hidden Reality, I still have to wonder that there may have been a clearer way to put forth those concepts to the reading public. Brian Greene is certainly game, as any good science teacher must be, for any and all manner of descriptions and analogies to illustrate ideas this exotic. But in looking for a way to make physics this otherworldly relatable, maybe he tries a bit too hard (or maybe the ideas are too hard) because his metaphors too often only barely translate the complexity and are sometimes, in his rare attempts to use pop culture, clumsy or distracting.Still, when Greene is successful in pinning down parts of these theories for us to see, the results are provocative, even transportive. Maybe this reveals my established interest in the subject but I found much of it, even the confusing parts, to be engaging. Greene's tone is not of a lecturer giving us rote directions but of someone who is trying to navigate these twisted paths along with us. The reader almost gets the sense he believes that if he can get us to understand these theories without the math, then that on its own will partially validate the mathematical work itself. That wouldn't be true of course, nor could he really believe it, but the attitude is appreciated.

This book offers a pretty dense overview of modern theoretical concepts about string theory, multiple universes, holographic universes, quantum multiple universes and computer generated universes. At the offset Greene explains that the book will provide information for a variety of readers- and suggests that the more well-read reader should skip past areas that are beneath her, while the lay reader can stop whenever she becomes saturated. The first couple of chapters rehash historical cosmology, the following chapters move into developments in science (though nothing really “new” to be told), before eventually delving into the speculative science. The speculative concepts could be considered mind-blowing, but many have gone a bit too far down the rabbit hole for me. I felt as though there were too many instances where Greene suggested that I “take a pass,” when in reality I was hoping for something more concrete or based in hard science to help ground it. I enjoy having my notions of the universe being challenged, but there was just not enough substance in many of the later chapters. At times it felt simply like he was just presenting mental concepts and this detracted from the overall authority of the book. The first half of the book is worthwhile for historical info and current M-theory explanations, but you can get this elsewhere. Overall the book was a disappointment.

I just finished this book and my brain hurts.I had read a previous book of Greene's and my memory told me that I had followed it pretty well. Now I'm not so sure. This is a pretty dense book to get through. It left me feeling like I don't know anything about the universe(s) around me. Greene looks at various and theories and ideas about the possibility of other universes existing outside (or within, or near) or own. He covers nine variations, from one's that lead from quantum and string theory, to ones that are much more conjectural. He does a good job of explaining, even if I didn't always do a good job of understanding. Good illustrations throughout help explain. Although he gives readers much appreciated permission to jump ahead to sections if they don't want to know how the quantum sausage is made, I gave it a shot anyways. I always felt I was right on the edge of grasping the concept, but not quite.Which is kind of where Greene says physicists and mathematicians find themselves in their quest to determine the existence of parallel universes through equation and experimentation. Overall, this is a great explanation of the scientific state of the art on this topic. Read carefully and with an open mind. It's pretty interesting stuff.

Brian Greene is one of the most brilliant minds in America (and the world). He has a gift, like Stephen Hawking, of makiing the incomprehensible comprehensible. He is one of our foremost theoretical physicists and a proponent of string theory. I was privileged to meet him several years ago in Washington D.C. and was impressed with his cordiality and easy manner. So, I've enjoyed "The Elegant Universe" and now "The Hidden Reality". The concepts presented are very difficult for Humanities majors, especialy ones who didn't take upper level Physics or Math. I read the book very slowly, only a few pages per sitting. Light bulbs went on regularly as I grasped the ideas Greene was describing, which support the likelihood of multiple universes, possibly an infinity of universes.One of my favorite pieces in the book is the possibility that we are living in a simulated universe within a computer program. If humans are able to simulate universes within computer programs in our future, and we are closing in on that possibility. Then, if there are many other universes, it is likely that creatures more advanced than we are have done so in the past. And that means we could be their simulation. If you are a sim, you would have no way of knowing it. Yikes!

Thought provoking and sometimes downright jaw dropping. Greene presents a case for why modern developments in physics may imply the existence of various different kinds of multiverses. His scientific explanations were difficult, but in my opinion, easier than Stephen Hawkings'. He has a great gift for using familiar analogies to explain concepts impossible to visualize, such as the 9 spatial dimensions of string theory, or quantum tunneling events. It turns out certain conceptions of a multiverse are a natural progression of some well established scientific theories such as quantum mechanics. Even more surprising is that nearly all of Greene's multiverses may someday be supported or contradicted by experimental evidence. Only one proposed multiverse he discusses is forever removed from any potential observation by principle. Before reading this book I had always thought of a multiverse as an obscure and unnecessary concept evoked arbitrarily by scientists for philosophical reasons. Greene managed to really shake my views by explaining that actual scientific principles give rise to various views of a multiverse. Our world is truly an amazing place that seems to become larger and more astounding with every generation of scientific advances.

I read this book for the "Deep Laws of the Cosmos" part of the title and not so much for the "Parallel Universes" part of the title. The book takes each potential parallel universe theory at a time and explains the physics behind each theory. For the most part, this results in a fairly good (though very basic) summary of quantum physics, gravity, relativity, string theory. However, sometimes the discussion of the physical laws (quantum probability, for example) gets divided between two or among several chapters instead of being cohesively presented together. This, of course, is because some aspects of the theory are necessary for the particular version of parallel universes being discussed in that chapter, while other aspects are necessary to other versions of parallel universe theories. I would have preferred a more cohesive exposition of the physical laws and a little less discussion of parallel universes. But that probably means I should have read a different book. And I think I will. That being said, I thought Brian Greene did a good job of making difficult theories and principles accessible. In fact, when I choose another book like this, I'll look for Brian Greene's name.

I enjoyed this book a lot, and it is really comprehensive in all the different options for parallel universes and the multiverse that it discusses. Although it was a general overview, they go into enough detail so that I actually learned a lot of new things from reading this. I especially thought the author's discussion about inflation and simulated universes were particularly well done.I found it was advanced enough to make it challenging to read at some parts, but it was also written clearly so it wasn't too difficult. The author writes very well and you can tell that he's really interested in the topics he's discussing. It definitely brings up many interesting questions about our universe and its place within a greater multiverse, and although we aren't in a position to answer those questions now, the author has really set the stage in where things are headed and new views we can take when developing theories.

I love reading Greene's stuff, even though I haven't a prayer of following the underlying math anymore. And he makes that, thankfully, unnecessary (unless you really want to dig into the footnotes).In this volume, he explains the concepts behind a wide variety of "parallel universe" hypotheses -- most of which I hadn't heard of before. I came to the book with the notion that it would treat just the famous (but nearly "traditional") Many Worlds hypothesis based on quantum mechanics, but that's just one of many examples here.I do think that the reader benefits from having read Greene's earlier books (or otherwise holding a layman's familiarity with the bare outlines of relativity, quantum mechanics, and string and inflation theory). Still, his explanations are quite clear for the purpose, his illustrations apt, and even his sillier examples are helpful.One minor gripe is that the inclusion of computer-based virtual worlds in his taxonomy seems a bit out of place, though the subject itself is of no small interest to me. All the other hypothetical parallel world systems stem from more basic physical concepts.For those interested in such things: recommended!

My background is mathematics and computer science with a fondness for cosmology and physics. I religiously watch the various science programs on PBS, the Science Channel, etc with their cursory overview of specific topics. Often they only rehash the same personalities with the same information from the last show I watched, which simply whets my appetite for more information. The Elegant Universe was the last of Greene's work I read, so chose The Hidden Reality for my latest science foray.Overall I found the work very approachable. His descriptions of string theory, branes, quantum mechanics, extra dimensions, and entropy were all accessible bringing the varied multiverse theories to life. Granted my brain did glaze over whilst working my way through the section on probability wave functions - but who's doesn't?! It even gave Einstein the willies... The one drawback is the overemphasis of Cosmological Inflation. But perhaps I only felt that because of the recent Scientific American essay authored by one Inflation's cocreators reconsidering the theory itself?But what does it all matter when we are just living in a simulation?

Meh. This book is, as the author readily acknowledges, long on speculation and short on evidence. The many universe theory is a charming, unexpected, but ultimately jejune interface of cosmology and metaphysics. The hard core science which drives the speculation cannot be explained without high level math. Those who can understand that math won't be satisfied with this book,which tries to accomplish such explanations without it. They should read the primary sources. Those who cannot understand the higher math will find the authors efforts here disappointing. Ultimately, I set the book down having completed only two-thirds of it. To end with some positive points: The author clearly knows his subject matter, and distinguishes between what is known and what is speculative. He gives a fair comparison of various theories which are all compatible with the current observational and experimental findings.One of the implications of the multiverse theory is that somewhere out there, there is a nearly identical duplicate of you, in fact an infinite number of them, and some of them, instead of reading this review, are just now finishing writing it. As I have.

Check out what I wrote in my blog: http://lunairereadings.blogspot.com/2...10-13-2011: Finished finally! Not very easy to understand; but very nice to read. I finished it with big effort; but I don't think that I got a lot of the things he said. However; I am looking forward to reading something else of this author in the near future.08-05-2011: I am trying hard to keep up with all the equations and mathematical explanations; but I have been about to give up. However; somewhere around chapter five; the author gave me the opportunity to skip some pages; and I did promptly and found out that the next set of pages was very entertaining and understandable. In sum; I am still struggling with this; but not yet abandoned it.I am still in the process of reading this book. It has been a nice surprise to be able to understand and follow the author's line of thought. He tries to prove that there are parallel universes; and that there are more than the three dimensions that we are used to live in.

I read this because I've always wanted to know more about the theories behind parallel universes and I thoroughly enjoyed Greene's Elegant Universe. I find string theory and physics fascinating. Now, the concept of the holographic universe seems intriguing, especially reading this after the Holographic Universe. Now, I have a better mathematical understanding of how the holographic universe theory was constructed, translating information between the math of quantum mechanics and relativity.Hmm. Elegant Universe was better than this in my opinion. There were parts of this text that got so deeply theoretical that I became discombobulated and disinterested. Then, the idea struck me. Why am I even reading about speculative theories about alternate universes that will never be possible to examine? All of these different types of possible universes seem too much for me right now. It's just solving puzzles with math and explaining mathematical anomalies. Wait...we might be in a simulated, Matrix-type universe? Perhaps, these ideas are interesting and just need to settle in my caffeine addled brain.

Brian Greene writes about difficult scientific concepts much better than most scientists who attempt to do so. A lot of the ideas in this book -- inflation, the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics, the holographic principle -- I have heard about before but feel that I understand much better after reading this book. Well, of course I would understand them better after repeated explanations, but Greene has a way of writing for the layperson without seeming to dumb down the material. He mainly does this through a steady stream of analogies and colorful illustrations, while being careful to often point out the limitations of such approximate imagery.Many people may be turned off by Greene's focus on string theory. He gives a rather exhaustive defense of the scientific merits of the continued pursuit of string theory absent the imminent ability of string theory to generate any testable hypotheses. The entire book is about theories of parallel universes, many of which by definition cannot generate testable hypotheses. He confronts head-on the question of whether theories such as these qualify as science, and gives what to me is a convincing argument that they do.

So, if you're the average person who enjoys learning the latest in science, and want to feel completely stupid, this is the book for you. I mean, obviously it's readable, because I read it - and enjoyed a lot of it! - but about 10% of it felt like it was completely out of my reach. So it was like seeing a puzzle that was 90% done. You get what it's supposed to be and where they're going with it, but it lacks clarity. It didn't help that every once in a while he would say, "the next couple of paragraphs get really complicated so feel free to skip to the next section." "Yeah right", I would think, "I'm no dummy. This isn't my first popular science book, after all." So I would read it. And get completely lost. I didn't even attempt to read the notes at the end.That being said, I found the topic fascinating and if you're ok with only understanding most of it, I would highly recommend it. I'll probably be reading Greene's other books. Because I'm a glutton for punishment. Or because I'm hoping that the more I read it, the better I'll be able to understand it. But something tells me that the only way I'll understand these books is to take a couple of courses in quantum mathematics...

I liked the overviews of where science is with things like string theory, quantum mechanics. Of course, you can't have those things without extra dimensions. Here's the best description of extra dimensions I've read yet - I felt I could almost grasp the idea for a minute before it unraveled in my head. Usually I just have to read through an author's description, then set it aside and say 'okay - let's just say there are extra dimensions'. This is valuable, because another big focus of the book is to discuss how theoretical physics keeps coming back to the idea of multiple universes. Greene steps through how several different multiverse theories have come about, how they work, and how they might / might not one day be tested. There's even a good discussion of a simulated universe. I'm going to admit that I got lost in the underlying details a few times, and did skim a section or two, but the themes of the book kept me on it. For those with a more solid physics foundation, there are lot's of notes for getting more deeply into the mathematics behind the topics.

Whew, this was a load! I enjoy reading Brian Greene's books, because they're filled with an awful lot of "blow your mind" moments. He does a great job of bringing his content to the masses, in a way that we can appreciate if not fully grasp. I have to say that there was a lot of material through the middle that I really had to work through. As always, he gives you the overview and then offers you the free pass of skipping to the next section if you think it might be a little technical. And, as always, I decline the offer and take it on. In the end, I'm glad I did. The prospect of infinite space implying infinite copies of me writing this review is so interesting, and I loved the chapter on simulated universes as well. This book makes you work for it, but perhaps that's why the payoff is worthwhile. I don't know if I'd last a week in one of his classes, but Brian Greene would probably be an interesting guy if you wanted to enjoy a cold one and be amazed at what's out there for us to discover.

The idea of parallel universes began with Everett Young, a graduate student whose thesis in quantum theory argued that the collapse of the Schrodinger probability wave upon measurement was not really a collapse: measuring a quantum state didn't just cause all states other than the one observed to disappear. Instead, Young argued, on observing a quantum system the universe splits so that each quantum state exists in one of the new universes. You, the observer, are in the universe where the outcome you see exists, and there are other YOUs that see the other outcomes.This was a very mysterious theory. Where are all these other universes? If you throw a die why should "reality" split into six different universe, one for each possible number of pips? It was considered quackery. But modern physics has increasingly accepted the idea, and Brian Greene--a real physicist and an outstanding writer--tells us how and why.For those interested in quantum physics and cosmology, this will be a great book. I certainly enjoyed it. It is the best exposition that I have read.

Two perspectives here. First, this book is phenomenal if you want to understand the ways in which physics and math suggest multiple/parallel universes. Second, you better get ready to give your brain a workout.The book is written for a largely general audience, so you don't need more than a passing familiarity with the concepts to get by. That said, even to provide a cursory overview of some of the topics requires mind bendingly complicated shifts in perception. Every think about all of reality as existing on a "flat" geometrical figure floating through a larger space? Well, get ready to, because the math says so. And that in the end is the question you're left with. Is reality just mathematics? Or is math simply a description of the fundamental reality that let's us make sense of what we see? I don't know. I'm moving on to Tegmark's 'The Mathematical Universe' next to try and make up my mind. Despite the deep metaphysical confusion I've been left with, if you're looking for a really good mind-wrinkling book, this is it.

Brian Greene is one of the best writers in popular physics. This book, The Hidden Reality, is no exception. Greene is a master at giving relatable analogies to explain some of the most difficult concepts in modern physics. The only drawback in this novel is the detail. At times, Greene will get overly bogged down in details that aren't necessary for grasping the overall concept. However, to his credit, he often does warn you in advance of delving into mathematical complexity.In short, this book suggests several possible parallel universes that emerge from theories in modern physics. Basically, the math that describes some proposed theory (like inflationary cosmology) brings along with it interesting solutions and possibilities (like a parallel universe). Right now, there is very little in the realm of parallel universes that can even begin to be explored observationally or experimentally. But that doesn't mean we should't consider it. Math has precipitated discovery many times in the past, and it will likely continue to lead us into the future.

Science was not a path I took in higher education, but I find many of the ideas and areas of research very interesting. The Hidden Reality is a great book for the layperson interested in physics and cosmology and the brain-bending theories that are at the leading edge. Greene starts by taking us through the centuries of theories and discoveries that got us to the science of today and then explains the implications of advanced physics in the various theories regarding the existence of a multiverse.While some of the theories are hard to grasp, Brian Greene is able to provide sign posts and descriptions using objects and ideas that are familiar to allow the reader/listener to take the mental leap into the unfamiliar ideas presented. This seems like material that can be revisited over time to clarify concepts as dictated by the reader’s interest.Audiobook VersionUnabridged / 13 hrs 48 minNarrator: Brian GreenePublisher: Books on TapeRelease: 01.25.11

This book was both entertaining and yet had a few parts that were very hard to get through. It's like a more readable and entertaining version of a Stephen Hawking book, in which the author attempts to explain complex theories of quantum mechanics, the big bang, and advance mathematics, while trying to render it approachable for the reader. He even invokes Cartman from Southpark to explain energy potentiality. That part was pretty odd! The author teaches physics at Columbia University, and is well-known for his work on String theory. He's appeared on PBS many times, and has been on Letterman a couple of times. An interesting side-note in the book is how discoveries in theoretical physics are leading to breakthroughs in Mathematics (e.g. complex 'Manifolds'). He also goes into parallel universes and probability theories, perhaps the most compelling aspect of the book. Worth reading if you're even remotely interested in this stuff.

I was so excited to pick up the latest Brian Greene book; after devouring "The Elegant Universe" and "Fabric of the Cosmos," I was certain that I would do the same here. I was mistaken. Without belaboring the point, two features of this book caused my interest to wane extremely quickly. First, there seemed to be an inordinate amount of "free-pass" statements from Mr. Greene. After the third time of reading "If you are reaching saturation, feel free to skip this entire chapter," I began to wonder if he had somewhat lost his previously uncanny ability to explain complex topics in a way that negated the desire to skip ahead. Second, nearly every "revelation" in this book followed up with the caveat that while it might be true, we don't (and may never have) the ability to prove it. The book quickly went from cutting-edge research to conversation points designed to sell a book. Overall, very disappointing.

This was a parallel look at parallel universes. (Sorry for the poor attempt at a pun, but it the book does go through nine different visions of the multiverse.) The author seemed to recognize that this might be a bit too technical (his words) or too detailed (my view). He referred several times to the method that the chapters are written in a overview -> deeper and deeper discussion so when you get "sick of it"/over-your-head the reader can just skip to the beginning of the next chapter. I found that there was too much detail on topics that someone who is likely to read this type of book has probably already gotten or read elsewhere. The specific example I remember was going over the double-slit. But then the logical story built on the "re-run" was pretty good. Overall, I enjoyed the "a bit too wordy/detailed" look at the multi-verse. I liked Greene's other books more, but this was still solid.

This book is more a flight of fancy for Greene than The Elegant Universe or the Fabric of the Cosmos. In those books he spent a lot more time explaining the fundamentals of Einstein’s theories and quantum mechanics as well as the reasoning behind string theory and some of string theory’s more immediate implications. Here, Greene relies on string theory to an equal degree as he does astronomy, simple logic, and philosophy to advance nine different arguments for believing that there are universes different than the one we are currently inhabiting and observing. He does an excellent job explaining complicated concepts in a way that is somewhat understandable to someone who does not have a background in theoretical physics, but even so some of his arguments simply seem like thought experiments that will never either be proven or disproven. I enjoyed the book and if you’re looking for something that considers the world and the universe from a unique perspective it’s worth picking up.

As a non-physicist, I am a fan of Greene, who is known for explaining string theory to the masses, but this book was a bit heavy for audio. I dropped off a couple times and had to re-listen to a few sections. Diagrams would be useful. I might have given it 4 stars if I read it in paper. Still, a thought-provoking read, if a little meandering.I have seen in other reviews that this book is not recommended for people new to theoretical physics. I agree with this. I have read a number of popular science books in the field and I think it helped my understanding of Hidden Reality. That said, I think that Greene bounces between the relatively advanced (9 models of multiverse) to the relatively novice (objectivity of maths, mind-body dualism etc)Probably could've used a bit more ruthless editing. I appreciate how Greene has recommended "skip ahead" points, but I don't know who would feel confident in taking advantage of these.

I've enjoyed all of Brian Greene's books that attempt to explain deep topics of physics and cosmology to laymen like me. While not an exception, found this the most difficult to get through, largely because the topical matter (the existence of parallel universes) was so far over my head. My 1970s undergraduate physics classes enabled to follow most of the items in his earlier works, but the concepts here are very difficult for the average person (ie, one like me without a grip on the deep math required for full understanding). Those with more recent and deeper scientific education may be able to appreciate this more than I can. That is, I greatly appreciate Mr. Greene's usually excellent ability to present deeply engaging topics in approachable language, but I couldn't quite get up to speed with this one.That said, I would highly recommend his earlier works (The Elegant Universe and The Fabric of the Cosmos) to just about anyone with an interest in this subject matter.

What if the universe as we know it were only one of possibly many? That is the fundamental question behind this latest book by physicist Brian Greene. Greene takes a very simplistic approach to things as he explains how scientists believe that our universe is not alone on its own & also describes the theories behind possible alternate universes & what they might look like. In each subsequent chapter we go further & further in depth into the concepts behind each of these possible variations in the multiverse & experience numbers on both sides of an extraordinary scale. It helps that while you don't have to have a complete understanding of current studies in the world of astronomy, physics or cosmology to make this book make sense. No matter what the thought that there could be other versions of us out there somewhere is still fascinating & proving this will be even more fun. Definitely a read for any of us who've wondered if parallel realities exist.

Speculative physics, described without the least whiff of mathematics, but with frequent mentions of the fact that the mathematics is actually very difficult, and that much of it is brand new.This is all about parallel universes, arising from string theory in about five different ways, from general relativity, from a particular interpretation of quantum mechanics, and from philosophy. Most of the string theory parallel universes seem to arise from the following argument:- here's a (mostly untestable) form of string theory.- you can apply a certain mathematical transformation to certain equations in this theory.- that transformation can be interpreted as representing a parallel universe.- therefore, the theory is compatible with the existence of parallel universes.- therefore, there might be parallel universes.Anyway, it's all vaguely interesting, but I didn't come away feeling that I had learned much.

This book has caused me to think a lot about my own existence as well as that of the rest of the universe.Why are we here? Where are we going? Is there something special about our reality (universe) or are we just one of some large number of realities? As always, Brian Greene does a very good job of explaining difficult concepts in physics for the lay man...and he supplements his discussions with endnotes for those who might want to know a little more. Greene discusses some of the amazing possible implications of various aspects of physics (inflationary cosmos, quantum mechanics, string theory, holographic projection) all of which might say deep things about our own reality or imply the existence of possibly infinitely many other realities that we will probably never get to observe. If you enjoy reading about physics and especially if you have a real sense of wonder about the universe we inhabit this is the book for you. In fact, its probably worth reading twice.

Brian Greene is a very good writer, his explanations seem to reliably deal with just the objection I was about to raise. That does not, however, make him right - especially when it comes to parallel universes of the dozen or so flavors he describes in this book.Among the questions Greene raises along the way is the nature of mathematics. Why does math work so well to describe reality and is there a sense in which math is 'real'? There are numerous examples of mathematical formulations that came to be applied outside the realm of their initial conception and led to new physical insights. Special Relativity was developed on the idea that the math of Maxwell's electromagnetic field equations could be understood to imply that the speed of light was relative to everything. General Relativity predicted black holes and an expanding universe, neither of which was expected or even believed by Einstein. On the other hand, must we believe in tachyons?

Greene certainly has a gift for analogy. For a layman curious about the fringes of cosmology, this is a cool read. A few parts were pretty mind-blowing. I struggled more than I'd anticipated, having to go back and re-read quite a bit, but I would've regretted skipping parts or speed reading or bailing altogether. Rife with jokes only science nerds can make, Greene made topics like string theory and quantum mechanics approachable. Denser material was mitigated with historical stories about scientists and Greene's own childhood musings and adult epiphanies. His (M-theory) duality analogy was probably my favorite thing; he compared the versions of it to one of those optical illusion pictures that looks like one famous person up close, but another when you back up. So yeah, The Hidden Reality is a challenging read but shrewdly lays out awe-inspiring material, while somehow also being fun.

I can't say anything in this review that has not already been said dozens of times in the hundreds of reviews here. In microcosm, this is a well written account of some of the research being done on the bleeding edge of the physics of multiple universes. Like his other books Dr. Greene has written for the layman and tries, and in most cases succeeds in making difficult concepts relatively clear in layman's terms. But it is wise to keep in mind that almost all of what is being talked about in this volume is entirely theoretical. Some physicists do not agree with Dr. Greene's String Theorist approach.Still it is interesting to see the direction being taken by some of the great names in Cosmology and Quantum Physics. While there is little chance that any of this material will be proven through experimentation in our lifetime, the consideration of such concepts fires the imagination and stimulates the creative mind to consider realms well outside the box of everyday thought.

This book discusses a motley collection of about 9 different physical and philosophical notions of alternative universes. Some modern physical theories seem to admit the distinct possibility that the universe we live in is not the only one.Greene is a working physicist and so knows his stuff better than a typical science writer who can only re-hash abilities and descriptions heard from experts. His metaphors are lucid, original, and framed within pleasingly-written chains of argumentation.Yet I thought much of the book was quite dull. The last two chapters, in particular, were quite tedious. And chunks of earlier chapters were also well outside my interests; indeed, at a couple of points Greene helpfully suggests that some chunks of the book can be skipped.This book might be a good resource for science fiction writers who want to invoke alternate universes using sciency language.

A bit of a letdown. Started out promising, with the trademark Greene conversational style and the relatively-interesting patchwork parallel universes. Somewhere toward the middle and the landscape multiverse, the book became quite plodding. I don't know if it's that the subject matter is just so dense that not even Greene can enliven it or what, but that section was a chore to get through.Eventually things got better, and we ended up on a higher note, so the book was not a complete loss. The discussion of Holograms and the Quantum Multiverse were interesting enough.I was pleasantly surprised to see the chapter on simulated universes, and the implications of same. It wasn't the sort of thing that came to mind when I heard of this book about parallel universes, but it was definitely worth consideration.

I've been reading this one in chunks for almost a year. It is incredible how something so completely non-technical can still be so _dense_. Greene has a true skill for taking extremely complicated material and translating it for a lay audience -- I actually felt like I was following well till it hit projections and black holes. He makes no effort to hide that his writing is biased towards his own philosophy and favorite theories, and I actually enjoyed a science writer who was so open about this fact. This is a great crash course in the current theories surrounding possible multiverses, by giving a clear snapshot of roughly where current physics stands, how the process of theoretical investigation works, and a humbling sense of just how much MORE there is to the topic than what is presented here. Be warned, despite being very much a popular science book, this is NOT a light read.

Maybe it was a mistake to listen to the audio version of this book. In spite of Greene's surprisingly good reading voice (I almost never enjoy authors reading their own books--it's usually best left to the pros) and his lovely writing, this is what I got out of the book--there are very likely parallel universes and those may come in sundry forms. Greene did tell me why he believes this, I just don't understand a word of it. I mean, I understood each word taken individually,but the sentences and paragraphs? Not a clue. Now, I have no physics background beyond knowing that if I drop something, it's going to fall, so Greene was working with poor soil when he was reading to me. However, if Greene is right, then in one of his parallel universes, I totally grok his book--I could freaking teach his book.
